comments.text:
Good stuff, appreciate your videos! However I don't think the wrist roller trains the opposite muscles (wrist extension in your example) on the way down, since your resistance is still in the same direction; the only difference is that on the way down it's resisting the weight falling down instead of bringing it up. It's just like the eccentric of a push up, which doesn't make it a pull exercise; it still uses the same muscles as the concentric. To turn the wrist roller into a wrist extension exercise you have to turn it around, so that the band hangs from the other side of the bar. Right?

I also like to train wrist radial and ulnar deviation (with a stick with weight on one end) as well as wrist pronation and supination (with something like a judo belt with weight plates hanging from it) and dumbbell finger rolls. As a climber I feel like this could help a lot in injury prevention.
comments.author: @kewner8556

comments.text: personally for me the neck/traps are very underrated as well! Loving the content man and thx for simplifying the youtube fitness space for us fellas üí™
comments.author: @Rakyr

comments.text: Amazing stuff man, I do have a question though. Do you do any body weight stuff during the week? Like 50 push ups every morning, etc? Or just the lifts? Should your chest be so sore you can't do push ups througout the week? Becuase if im hitting chest once a week hard (which I agree with) is it gonna hurt to add some body weight just to have something to do exercise wise during the week to help me wake up / stimulate my muscles? Hopefully that makes sense! This question could also apply to things like body weight squats, arm curls, etc. Movements that people have historically added to their daily routine.
comments.author: @DadsReadAlongStories

comments.text: I like neck is underrated in my opinion they are also visible an most people don't train it because if they saw somebody doing a neck exercises it looks werid but your neck is used to keep your spine and head stable and strong. comments.text: Sleep is the one thing I need to work on.
comments.author: @seekertosecrets7618

comments.text:
You know what the worst part of this is?
You are correct.

Ive been training and checking what i eat for about more than a month now. Before that i started walking and some cardio.
Im slowly getting stronger and slowly lose fat but also gain muscle.
Can do a full set of pushups now and probably can do my first pullup soon too.
This was impossible for me before i started. I didnt exercise at all.

Consistency just works, but it is slow. And if things slow down, i probably only need to change something small and continue.
You know what sucks most about this? There is no magic. 

No special thing that makes this faster (without extreme drawbacks).
No "hack" that makes it easier.
No Supplement that makes this effortless.

There is no shortcut. "Keep it simple stupid". 
From my experience, which isnt too much yet but still,
start with something. Even "just" walking will do a lot for you. And then slowly add more to it over time.
comments.author: @Jadenyoung1

comments.text: Hey awesome video, my only question is how many sets should I do? I've been doing 2 sets to failure on every exercise for a while now, but should I do more sets for compounds and less sets for isolation? For example, 4 sets of bench press and 2 set of lateral raises. Or am I overthinking and 2 sets for every exercise is totally fine as long as each one is pushed to failure. I have this concept in my mind that spamming sets on isolation exercises is pointless, but doing more sets on compound lifts is worth it because of the additional muscles being activated. Thanks anyway, very helpful video.
comments.author: @32ducky

comments.text: i am the perfect subject for this plan. i am single and work a full time job. i want to be healthy and look healthy/fit. but i dont want to go 6x a week. going to start this plan 3x a week. maybe 4 if i get in the groove. i need to shred 15-20 lbs. ive lost it before but it slowly creeps back up so i know i can lock the diet in. i will also mix in some carido since i am trying to lose weight. thanks and wish me luck. so sick of being average and lacking the confidence i deserve to have
comments.author: @jimlaheylovesrandy

comments.text: One guy told me to go to failure on ever set, I can‚Äôt understand how to track progress like that. Looking forward to the new year and finding your yt channel! Happy holidays

comments.text: My biggest issues since this past year has been not doing progressive overloading until about a month ago. I been doing the same lifts (with variations and occasionally swapping to mix things up) at the same weight. I‚Äôve been lifting on and off for a few years and now I‚Äôm kicking myself in the butt for not overloading as I should‚Äôve. I completely undermined my strength and now I truly see myself getting stronger.
comments.author: @iOnyxOnyx

comments.text: I did the typical bro split for the whole year 2025, im not that jacked, about 5'8 155-160 pounds lean. comments.text: My brothers and sisters... Working out has been so overcomplicated by social media. Although its not necessarily easy, It's actually very simple to put on muscle. Stick to the basics. Great vid for the newcomers btw.
comments.author: @Jonnyhere

comments.text: I recently started my fitness journey on a serious note. And I was so happy to see most of the workouts I do matched what you suggested. And m more motivated after watching your video. You explained it in very simple and easy way and were very polite and sounded like a gentleman. Thanks so much. ‚ù§‚ù§ Hello from New Delhi , India. And the key take away for me is to stay consistent. thanks again.
comments.author: @ivanswarovski4811

comments.text: instead of incline dumbell flies, i prefers doing incline cable flies. it feels super comfortable on my shoulder, without any pain but just enough stress on my chest muscles.
comments.author: @astrrofn5107

comments.text: 4:10 made me happy! I do that same form leaning back, while the legs look weak barely supporting this movement. lol I never see anybody else do it like this beside me
comments.author: @mattursua2546

comments.text: I only do three days each week at the gym 1. Arms 2. Seated low row and chest press 3. Leg press. And I do the plank everyday before bed. That seems to work really well for me and targets my whole body üòä I‚Äôm seeing really good results with this gym plan.
comments.author: @jameswarden9136

comments.text: Awesome pics. Great size. Look thick. Solid. Tight. Keep us all posted on your continued progress with any new progress pics or vid clips. Show us what you got man. Wanna see how freakin' huge, solid, thick and tight you can get. Thanks for the motivation.
comments.author: @ghlibisk67

comments.text: Quick question: on upper days should I do chest exercises back to back then back exercises back to back? Or split them up so I do one chest exercise, then one back exercises, etc
comments.author: @gberky

comments.text: Hi, I‚Äôm a little confused. Your workout plans include more and different exercises, but in this video you say it only takes a few.
comments.author: @MarcusInd3p3ndence

comments.text: its great to see my mindset match 100% to yours and seeing i have been training for about 1 and a half years now i know i have no excuses to not get jacked
comments.author: @Blendette

comments.text:
Found out I was pretty much doing this full workout already and found out in 7 minutes why it's good and why it's working. 

Absolutely cut all the extra noise around it out of the video. 
 
Subscribed then and there. 
A well earned sub. I wish everything was this easy to understand
comments.author: @themightychippy3756

comments.text: Straight bar is so bad it hurts my wrist personally.
comments.author: @ethancbaker2002

comments.text: Do you find too much pressure on the chest and ribs during chest support tbar rows? Kinda uncomfortable but I still do them sometimes
comments.author: @danejdevos

comments.text: What does my free testosterone need to be at to see results from my workouts?  Above 5.1 ng/dL?  Above 0.5 nmol/L?
comments.author: @bwfrieds

comments.text: S tier - Diet and consistency.
comments.author: @ericpadilla2454

comments.text: Can I ask you a question? How many sets of these do you do‚Äîincline dumbbell presses(etc)?
comments.author: @szubacs

comments.text: no glute work, great work on teaching people to get injured and have knee problems later in life
comments.author: @fraserpye9667

comments.text: I wish my gym had the incline chest fly machine, it looks great. best alternative i found for it was using a incline bench and putting it between two cable flys. worked wonders for my upper chest!
comments.author: @anthonysane

comments.text: No preacher curls no baysien curls, are these help or just incline curls are best?
comments.author: @viratsingh9600

comments.text: hardly disagree with incline (or any other) dumbbell fly. it has 0 resistance at the top part of the exercise in the direction that you want.  any kind of cable-based fly is superior over dumbbells
comments.author: @justas3000

comments.text: Any tips on growing the traps? Mainly the upper part?
comments.author: @light6069

comments.text: Probably the best video of ranking S tier exercises brother I've been doing all the exercises you've mentioned and it works and the most effective yet also best way to get jacked .‚ù§
comments.author: @Ashutosh-1101

comments.text: Pretty close to my S-Tier list, and a lot of these selections were to protect/strengthen against injuries that a lot of popular lifts don't address. Nice!
comments.author: @GearHeart_22

comments.text:
I started training in 1978 when I was 14. Two years before that, I threw out my back shanking a punt during football‚Äîended up with spondylolisthesis in my L5-S1. Doctors told me not to lift, said it would make it worse. My back was so unreliable I‚Äôd often sit out gym class, until an 8th grade teacher warned me I wouldn‚Äôt get away with that in high school.

Everything changed when my youth football coach‚Äôs son took me down to their basement and showed me his barbell set. I tried a bench press, then a curl‚Äî95 lbs. on each, sloppy as hell, but I got them up. I was hooked. Got my own barbell set the following Christmas.

My goal wasn‚Äôt to get big‚Äîit was to get strong. All I had to go by was the wall chart that came with my 110 lb. Diversified Products set from Sears (where my dad worked) -- cement inside with a plastic coating.  I followed it religiously. And I got strong‚Äîeven more once I got an adjustable bench w/leg extension the next year.

But something else happened. I hit my growth spurt hard. Between freshman and sophomore year, I went from 108 lbs. to 162 lbs. People noticed. Friends asked about my bench, teachers told me I looked good. That‚Äôs when I got serious‚Äîbooks, a chin-up bar in my doorway,  learning about diet. The muscle came as a byproduct of getting stronger.

I never looked back. Never had interest in stepping on a bodybuilding stage‚Äînot even once. But I did turn it into a career as a pro wrestler. That strength paid off in other ways too, like working as a land surveyor and being able to remove 230 lb. manhole covers by myself, one-handed.

Eventually, you realize you can only grow so much. The rest of the journey is about holding onto what you‚Äôve built‚Äîand fighting like hell not to lose it.
comments.author: @firebird7479

comments.text: I don't know man, the body shown as a proof of being "skinny beginner" is pretty much all I'd ever need.
comments.author: @AnssiEriksson

comments.text:
I agree. I decided to change my workout plan based on the time I have available.

Upper Day 1(Chest and Back Focused): 3 Back Exercises(3 sets each), 2 chest exercises(3 sets each), 1 bicep(2 sets) and 1 tricep(2 sets) exercise. Max Time taken 45-50 Minutes.

Legs + Shoulders 1: 2 Quad Movements, 3 shoulder movements, 1 hamstring movement and 1 calf movement+3 Sets of Hammer Curls(50 Minutes to 1 hour depending on my rest time)

Rest Day

Upper Day 2(Bicep and Tricep focused): 2 Biceps Exercises(3 sets each), 2 triceps exercises(3 sets each), 1 chest exercise(2 sets), 2 back exercises(2 sets)(45-50 Minutes total again)

Legs+Shoulders 2: Same as the first one.

4 days a week with 3 rest days. Have been managing extremely well and it doesn't feel like I'm missing out. High Intensity too.

What is your personal opinion on this?
comments.author: @radicaldrake7064

comments.text:
Working out is literally just discipline and patience. 

Most people lack the two, and that's why they're always frustrated. 

Want the results you desire? Do the same thing literally every single day, without fail, and you'll see results over time. PPL 6 days/week, 7-8 hours of sleep daily, eat the same food every day. No ifs ands or buts.

comments.text:
Intuitive training is good; it depends on your experience. You can always progress, especially if you train to failure. If your sets are hard enough, you don‚Äôt need to track every weight, but noting your main lifts once a month is a good way to check if you‚Äôre truly progressing.

Muscles don‚Äôt see numbers‚Äîthey respond to hard work and progressive overload. Tracking can make linear progression easier, but if you push all sets to failure, your body will naturally adapt and you‚Äôll increase weight intuitively over time.

Bad intuitive training is what you described in the video: training comfortably, constantly changing exercises, chasing pump. That leads to minimal gains.

Good intuitive training, on the other hand, is hard, structured, and consistent. If you listen to your body, train hard, and track main lifts occasionally, you don‚Äôt need to log every set.

Tracking everything can be useful, especially for beginners, but the key is finding the right approach for yourself. Some people thrive on high volume, some on lower volume. Some succeed purely intuitively, others with detailed tracking. There is no universal optimal method.

Training smart and hard is the universal key to your dream body.

I‚Äôd love to hear your opinion on this because I‚Äôm always learning and could be wrong. Love your channel‚Äîit helps people stop wasting time in the gym and start training really hard instead of just long.

Take care, brother!
comments.author: @AdmandGaming

comments.text: A common problem in assessing progress is switching around the workouts so often that it becomes impossible to know whether or not you're getting stronger. And make no mistake, STRENGTH is the goal. Judging progress based on body weight will only incentivize weight gain. But the rate of muscle growth is too slow to be useful here. If you are getting measurably stronger on each workout (or nearly so), then muscle growth WILL follow. Now, once you're focused on getting more reps with more weight, then a second common problem arises. You must perform the same exercises for an extend period as mentioned previously, but YOU ALSO MUST maintain the same form and rep cadence. If you are going slow, smooth, and strict one week, but you up the weight and start slinging the weight to get your reps, then are you getting stronger? PROBABLY NOT. You have to keep all the parameters constant in order to assess progress. The only things that should change are the # reps and resistance used. This is how you KNOW you are making progress. "The first principle is that you must not fool yourself - and you are the easiest person to fool." Richard Feynman
comments.author: @MarcosBuenijo1973

comments.text:
I‚Äôve been skinny for years, and before that I was extremely overweight in my teens. I lost weight, but it came with years of an eating disorder, which eventually put me in the hospital because I became dangerously skinny.

Over the past year, I‚Äôve been going to the gym, but more recently I found your videos. I actually log my workouts now, watched your 180-day video, and follow a lot from it. I also keep track of your other videos and apply them to my training. I‚Äôve been doing this consistently for four months.

I see so many changes in the mirror my glutes, biceps, a V-line‚Äîand I don‚Äôt look so skinny anymore. I don‚Äôt look ‚Äújacked,‚Äù but I look like I go to the gym, which for me means everything. I don‚Äôt want to get big like a bodybuilder. My goal is simply to look at myself and love who I see.

I still have a long road ahead, but I just want to say thank you. I feel happier, I‚Äôve been going to the gym 3‚Äì4 times a week for a year and two months, and I‚Äôm now 8 months sober from my eating disorder.
 So Thank you
comments.author: @RafieTV

comments.text:
I find it so Hard to level on the squats.. I actually went back a few weights, just to control the form, and do a little more reps.

The pull-ups is the same.. gain like 1 rep in two years, from 10 to 11.

Also the dumbell press. Just stuck at the same weight with 5-7 reps.

Edit: I might have fluctuated around my weight, with 1-4 kg body weight back and forth. Obviously I feel stronger when +4kg than staying -4kg at my usual weight.

I am training consistently for 2 years now, upper lower, but find it hard to add more reps each week.

Please help me out!

comments.text: I have ADHD and I used to get really overwhelmed from the amount of info out there. I became a perfectionist about what I see on the scale and would stop with my nutrition and fitnesss because I thought I couldn't be consistent enough. Channels like yours and getting help from my gym buds made me totally consistent the past 15 weeks. I keep things simple, track my workouts, and built an easy nutrition plan. The results are insane. Your videos really help guys like me man.

comments.text:
I think this is what I‚Äôm missing. I‚Äôm going to listen to ya. Track my workouts and progress with reps and added weight. 
So every week should I just set a goal like 5 x10 of bench press for 95lbs ,then next week go for 100 lbs for 5x10 until that‚Äôs mastered. And so on. ? Or should I do 95lbs for 5x10 then add reps so 95lbs for 5x15 ? Then after that move on to more weight? 
Sry that‚Äôs a lot but need help here.

comments.text:

comments.text: I think these videos are probably oriented more towards guys, but as a woman who's looking to get huge for my frame, I still get all the value out of them. I don't feel 'left out' or 'excluded', which is really rare in this space. Thanks for making your content, and please keep going!
comments.author: @Suspicious-Mouse

comments.text:
48 years of training and I do none of this -- except hang on a chin bar and light stretching of the pecs, shoulders and lats. I jump right in to my heaviest set. Then knock off 10% each subsequent set. Example: This morning I walked into the gym at 7:50 AM, hung from the chin bar for 30 seconds, did my pre-workout stretch, then went for my first set of seated cable rows: 210 lbs. for 7 reps, then 190 for 8 reps on the second set; 170 for 9 reps on the third set. Heavy to light gets your heaviest weight when the muscle is fresh, making the lighter poundages harder in the sets after. 

Walking on a treadmill or a stair stepper has never worked for me as a warm-up.  I do that separately, as well as stretch post-workout which includes band work. I get my mind ready in the shower and on the way to the gym. This works for me.

As Vince Gironda said, "Your first set is your warmup set." There are no such things as "warm up sets", "ramping sets" or "work sets". That's gimmickry and "bro science". I hate that phrase.  EVERY SET YOU DO IS A WORK SET.
comments.author: @firebird7479

comments.text:
When I was a competing powerlifter I could spend up to 30 minutes just doing mobility. I do hit some mobility work now, specifically for the low back & hips but I do like 10 mins now & that's it. I genuinely think foam rolling is a waste of time. 

I do full mobility run throughs now on off days, 20mins-25mins are spot on. I'd suggest Tom Morrisons channel on here. But you cannot beat going through a full range of motion, with weight to improve your mobility. 

Most days I've been out walking for 45 mins or so before I lift, a walk really does "get you moving" 

üôè
comments.author: @beans8130

comments.text:
Man in all honesty, your point of view was very refreshing and it helped me alot with rescheduling my training routine. 
Keep being a Role model! Thank you ü§ùüí™

comments.text:
Do you eat less on rest days than training days? I‚Äôm currently in the process of cleaning up my diet a bit since I dirty bulked from ~9%BF to ~15%BF. I find that I‚Äôm always mentally craving sweet things still tho like cereal on top of my yoghurt fruit bowl, peanut butter and jam, medjool dates, honey and bananas, etc.

Also if I‚Äôm lean bulking and don‚Äôt wanna track (and dinner is different each day), is a good approach to eat 3 massive meals a day and visually try to match across each day?

comments.text: Hey I had a query, I have been following you for workout routine and you have been suggesting 4 workout a week routine. I wanted to know that how can I add cardio in all this, I add running in my routine so can it be that I lift 4 days and then in the rest 3 days, I give for running?? Does that become 6 days workout week?? My main problem is, If I don't get a good workout and get to move my body, I don't feel good. It opens up my brain and mood. So yes I can Incorporate 4 day lift per week, but what about the rest days? I'm interested in martial arts, Calisthenics and running....

comments.text:
A simple 10-12 minute incline walk has worked for me for a while now. Just enough to get a tiny sweat going with a hoodie on.

Usually 2 warm up sets of my main compound lift. Then we hit working sets. Always brace for impact with the üòØ face taking in a sharp breath of air and exhale at the end of the rep.

Forget everyone else is in the room. It‚Äôs you and the lift. Lock in and attack it

comments.text: this guy is a pure gem in fitness industry
comments.author: @aniket4627

comments.text: Physical therapist here. Keep up the good work! I can‚Äôt tell you how many patients I see have injuries from working out 6 days a week. As we get older, our bodies need the rest days and good sleep. Love the content!
comments.author: @LeeDPT

comments.text: Great advice. I'm currently doing single sets to failure, slow and steady, good range of motion, pausing for breath and poise, tracking my lifts, staying consistent. I'm getting more out of my workouts than ever before: making gains, staying injury-free, recovering quickly, feeling fitter, stronger and more energetic in life. I love the gym but you have to make it work for you, not the other way round - especially if you're older...
comments.author: @joelonsdale

comments.text: that gym is soo sick
comments.author: @puffgod3

comments.text: For older lifters, pausing at the top and bottom and going slow without any jerkiness and going to failure leads to maximum muscle growth and minimum chance of injury. Avoiding injury is paramount. I do just two sets for the main muscle groups but go maximum effort perfect form, every other day. It's plenty of effort.
comments.author: @100toeface

comments.text: Thanks for answering my question awhile back this is awesome.i get it now. by the way. Just to share my POV. Being able to recover more, people around me start noticing my physique. Back then I used to train like crazy for years. 5-6 days a week. All it did was, sometime ago lifting with em boys, most of the time injuries, and really really dead fatigue to a point I cant think straight due to severe lack of focus. Yes I did somehow reach my goals but at what risk. What you said its absolutely true. Recovery is dead important. Now I focus on that.
comments.author: @hamsterdamdam

comments.text: What‚Äôs funny is that the ‚Äúweeds‚Äù as you call it is what got me into lifting. I love nerdy, nitty, gritty number stuff so I researched and researched all this hyperspetfic cues and exercise selection and after 6 months I was like why don‚Äôt I try it out and loved it. But I wouldn‚Äôt recommend most people do it. When someone asks my I simply and express that commitment and consistency are the key 80% to 90% of what works
comments.author: @hansdykstra3869

comments.text: Does a person need to do forced reps, like do 2 more reps, than you could  naturally do, with a spotter, on  the last 2 sets after getting  warmed up?  That is the way I was taught, and the way everyone trained in the 80's and 90's.  Is that the best way or not?
comments.author: @michaelcraig9449

comments.text:
thank you after watching your video about protein I didn't buy Whey protein and sticked to getting it from my diet
but what about Creatine? I'm a complete 25 years old beginner so do you think it would help ?
comments.author: @bo34-y4e

comments.text: Thats how i do it aswell. I appreciate that you have time to mentally prepare for the next rep, especially the closer you get to failure. Its like mustering up all your strenght and focus for the next rep coming.
comments.author: @matthiasryser6305

comments.text: Nah... you gotta throw the weights down, yell like you're trying to shit out a housebrick, then leave all the 'bells & plates scattered around the gym floor. Don't forget to leave all the machines loaded just so everyone knows how heavy you lifted. Finally, make sure to leave your empty tren vials in the locker room - your mom will come along soon to tidy up after you like she always does...
comments.author: @neilwheel

comments.text: I started training 3 years back. I used to get into my head about grips, negatives, pauses etc. I realised that it's all about you enjoying the process. Train hard, sweat hard, eat hard, sleep hard ! That's it!!!
comments.author: @Gym-and-Jesus

comments.text: I feel the weights much better in the target muscle when I pause. I love it. Lower a little slower controlled, pause and think about using the muscle then boom. Repeat. All the science and studies stuff has really detached me from watching weight lifting content on YT now. I‚Äôm very grateful for it as well. Do what feels right to you, have fun, push yourself and rest.
comments.author: @MTheory333

comments.text: Yep, basics programs like 20-30 year's ago for couple years and you will be good. But that doesn't sell on yt and insta
comments.author: @emate8422

comments.text: I find Paused Reps effective, easy and difficult all at the same time. I do a lot of my exercises with a not so deliberate paused rep. It just happens naturally to me as I always prefer a slow and controlled negative pretty much on everything. And adding a split second pause helps that cause.
comments.author: @rishabhbose29

comments.text: If you do this I think you would have to make sure to repeatedly reconnect with the muscle during every pause rest on each rep. So repeated mind to muscle connection will need to be recreated for each rep.
comments.author: @balla2828

comments.text: That T Bar machine looks too official, I‚Äôve never seen one like the one you showed. It‚Äôs hard to find gyms that have any T Bar setups. I grew the most back muscles from the T Bar. It just works for me.
comments.author: @micaheldey1981

comments.text: Number one rule....have fun and lift the way you enjoy. Just be smart and don't hurt yourself
comments.author: @austinrandall1273

comments.text: Hey, just wanted to let you know I sent you an email with a short edited sample using a fragment of your film. It‚Äôs only about a minute long, so it‚Äôs quick to watch. I‚Äôd love to hear what you think when you get a moment.
comments.author: @Barteqq11

comments.text: Another winner!  Very impressive calves. Question. Do you still do 3 sets of 8 to 12 reps even with calf raises and forearm exercises?
comments.author: @domjohndemarco

comments.text: Also, many American adults barely move, like sloths. So, if you go for walks, and touch weights, or do anything physical, then you're already doing something.
comments.author: @maxmeeks9910

comments.text: Gym coach for employed casuals. Refreshing. Different from the ranked unemployed gym rats
comments.author: @TheJan

comments.text: Thats Mentzerizm with a twist, and i like it. Its just that simple guys, no need to overcomplicate simple things :) Shock the body > let it rest > let it grow > repeat.
comments.author: @greypant7204

comments.text:
Thank you, Eric, for the simplification of my weight training routine.  
I can have my life back.
I am forever grateful.
comments.author: @gregoryowen841

comments.text:
Finally someone said it. 

I was intermittent fasting, only getting two meals a day, lost 20lbs, def under ate my protein and my numbers in the gym kept soaring higher and higher. It‚Äôs all a gimmick
comments.author: @donnylem8818

comments.text:
Those recommendations are atypical (2g per kg is just the "safe number", not the recommended minimum. The usual range is 1.2-1.6...) and companies selling protein pudding really aren't part of the fitness industry, they're just commerce being commerce. They're selling you vegan water as well but nobody sane is gonna pretend like they're part of some vegan movement. Listening to nutritionists giving you average numbers for the general population is also wrong because they're giving you numbers for sustaining a healthy life with some light to moderate fitness like 2 runs a week.

Yes, the industry is wrong for most people because it takes a ceiling for the 5% and pretends like every average lifter needs to go there. But there's no need to reach like that. Throwing the pendulum the other way helps no one.
comments.author: @Hosenanzugtasche

comments.text: When i was 17 i gained 10kg of bodyweight and developed my body the way it is today. Only eating 95% carbs and training hard as f*ck. when i was walking back home, i used to stop at a dunking donuts store and buy a box of  six donuts and walk back home eating it. When i got home, used to eat 6 french breads with butter and jelly and drink a liter of milk, was never a great protein eater, used to eat one chicken beef ta lunch. Now i'm 48 and have 85kg, 43kg of muscle and around 12-15% of boddy fat. All because of what i built in that time. And i'm still eating loads of carbs, and the bare minimum of protein. The training is mixed, tomorrow, a 5k run targeted at a 27' mark, low to high.
comments.author: @rudolph3058

comments.text: I believe, in my opinion, it's the amount your body can absorb and utilize for maintenance and repair at a given time- just enough to avoid catabolism and maintain anabolism. I used to injest liquid amino acids combined with a mineral supplement of calcium and magnesium with yogurt an hour before training.  Avoided long digestion times and worked quickly in increasing my lifting strength. Any amount over is either stored or depleted....and there are still some medical professionals claiming the controversial opinion that high animal protein damages kidneys. Carbs are very important for the energy required for lifting and for filling out your muscles. Notice how huge your muscles look the day after you lift. Carbs retain water-muscles mostly water.
comments.author: @johnstelluto9101

comments.text: it takes 2.5 grams of leucine to trigger the mtor switch ( anabolism ) along with the other 9 essential aminos which basically means eating about 25 to 40 grams of complete protein depending on the source, once mtor is activated it will take a minimum of 3 hours before you can flip that switch again, so 3 to 4 meals with 30 grams of protein in each over the course of 9 to 12 hours is the best you can really do, breakfast, lunch, dinner, with a complete protein source and enough overall calories to support training hard and recovery is the best you can do, it's just normal eating but focusing on getting protein in each meal
comments.author: @terrytibbs1040

comments.text: Enjoyed the talk. You did say though that at 185lbs you have about 140g of protein. That is still a lot. To seek out meals that would total 140g of protein per 24hrs is still being very "protein thinking". So I don't really get what the big lie is? It's already extremely well established that we need protein to repair and grow muscle...and you seek out 140g per day. I think if you are saying that you don't need the sometimes suggested 1g per 1b of bodyweight and that 0.6g to 0.8g per lb is sufficient, then yes that's fine. It's not exactly the "Biggest lie in the Fitness Industry" though...
comments.author: @DuncanWalshWorkoutPlans

comments.text: 0:51 I find it baffling, how could someone critique your form? Full range of motion, dead stop at start of each rep and each set close to or to failure, arent all of these what the "science bros" been preaching for years?üòÖ These ppl are either straightup tarded or they were trying to bully because you just started your channel.
comments.author: @fourtii8707

comments.text: Those medical studies also show that the higher end, the .8 grams per pound, is pretty much only for professional level lifters. Your average gym goer doesn't need that much either.
comments.author: @Jushtan-g3y

comments.text: Hey bro question when doing the lat pulldown, do you feel your biceps too? comments.author: @TradingWithSergueev

comments.text: im doing 400g of chicken brest on grill + 6eggs boiled + 100g of mozzarela melted on the chicken + 80g of bacon, i dont use seedoils to cook. comments.text: Wow! So many lives wasted due to insecurity. Getting "jacked" fixes nothing. All "jacked" guys have tiny pee pees before and after lifting weights and women know this. All muscle men might as well wear a shirt that says "I HAVE A MICRO"!!! Everybody knows.

comments.text: I‚Äôve recently found this out through my own experience. I‚Äôve always had a mass mindset. comments.text: one of the biggest lies is how much protein the fitness influencers tells you how much you need... i can LITERALLY get 80-120g and i get insane development, and it wont see a difference if i instead over 6 month took 190g, what REALLY matters is if your body feels sore even though you train alot, its probably because your muscles are not getting enough protein to repair it self fast enough

comments.text: I have been thinking this for a long long time. comments.text: True. I was stating this a long time ago and i am happy that more and more people find out about the protein lie. comments.text: I agree 100%, in my opinion 0.7g of protein per pound of lean body weight is more than enough. comments.text: I nowadays do 2 full body workouts a week. And I feel like this is working better for me than 3 days of ppl. I can hit full body twice and get away without over training. üí™üèª
comments.author: @fahiim_x

comments.text:
This is how I train lately too, and it's been excellent.

Basically at some point I realized that the only way to balance high intensity progressive overload with adequate recovery was to manage my volume. I started focusing on quality of sets rather than quantity, and everything came together.

Love your channel - nothing too flashy or gimmicky, just straight to the point, sensible, and clear. I think lot of people really need to hear this.
comments.author: @takewithfood

comments.text: I do a full body 2-3 days per week. Still have my six pack
comments.author: @dr.kurtjohnson1791

comments.text: I have been training three times a week for months using a push/pull/full body system (Sat, Sun, Wed). For each session and each muscle, I only do 3-4 hard sets to failure, followed by 2 pump sets fpr each muscle with 20-30 reps and light weights (similar to the FST-7 concept). Even after many years of doing this, I am still making good progress.
comments.author: @jensb661

comments.text: Just watched your last 3 vids. Man I've been looking for you. I've put off going to the gym for years because I can't afford a trainer and just dunno what the hell to do. I'm going to get your course and change my life now thanks brother!

comments.text: Great stuff, man. I‚Äôve been following this same routine 3‚Äì4 times a week for the past six years, while keeping my diet and sleep consistent, and I couldn‚Äôt agree more with what you‚Äôre saying. Over time, you really start to see how powerful the basics are. It‚Äôs not about chasing new programs or doing anything extreme‚Äîit‚Äôs about mastering the fundamentals and sticking with them. Some weeks the progress is obvious, other weeks it‚Äôs subtle, but it‚Äôs always adding up in the background. That long-term consistency builds not just physical results, but discipline and confidence too. Six years in, it‚Äôs clear that showing up regularly and trusting the process beats any short-term motivation. Consistency really is the key! ü¶æ
comments.author: @alexsoccer899

comments.text:
In Australia its summer, Ive neen full of big gym energy since spring, workouts are next level! 

Winters get heaps cold where I am and daylight hours drop down. I still gym consistently, no issues there, but I'm definitely slower and miss that backup determination. How do you keep your mental state up in winter?  

Fyi this year I accepted it as slower/ form focussed recuperation time and I count down the days. I had a much easier winter and I came back swinging in Spring!
comments.author: @Aiden214

comments.text: Its just time consuming. Even actors who get into peak shape within 6 months eat 4-5k calories a day with so much of it being protein and then the intense workouts. People want instant results rather than long term progress. I do get it though. I went from bodyweight dips to adding 45 lbs for 8 reps a year later and I didnt look any bigger but I clearly was stronger. It's part of the reason I quit the gym for a while. Between the cost, the weather and just not seeing the physical mass development I wanted I was less inclined to keep going to the gym.
comments.author: @teartrapz2897

comments.text:
Advocating for people to walk 10 fucking thousand steps a day is ridiculous and instantly made me stop the video. Shit will take several hours to do (minimum 2 if you're walking normally and are able to do so), something normal people with jobs do not have the time or energy for. Low effort my ass. 
Not to mention you're saying we don't need to spend 2 hours in the gym to get results, then pivot to spending 2 hours walking. Fantastic.
comments.author: @Jimmykreedz

comments.text: Love the "sunlight asap" message.  UV light turns on so much in the brain and the lack of UV light turns so much off.  We are meant to be awake during the day and sleep at night.  Just think of the last time you had a power outage for a couple of days and went "It's dark and I'm bored... I guess I will go to sleep."  What time did you wake up in the morning?  I got money on dawn and would double down on the feeling of wanting to get the day started.
comments.author: @LetsPlaywithDDae

comments.text:
Agree.  
Im 42 now,  im i ve been training 5x a week for years,  and i dont see that much progress.
I train well... Push pull leg with weight progression... doing everything slow and focused,   most of the time try to eat well... But i feel that im not getting better.  

From January 2,  i will start a 3x full body training with heavy weight and low reps,   keep with 200gr of protein a day,  and including 3 or 4 days of 10k steps
comments.author: @psychoGamesStudios

comments.text: I actually found out that consistency is the key and to be consistent you have to have fun. If you don‚Äôt have fun while at the gym then you don‚Äôt need to go there and you do it just because of the hype around fitness. I personally found out that I have fun when running and hiking and that‚Äôs all I‚Äôm doing, and also some body weight exercises that I like. Pumping iron was not for me even though I have good genetics. It‚Äôs probably weird to see a big guy with wide shoulders like me to run a lot but it‚Äôs so fun for me that I can‚Äôt help it lol
comments.author: @yuru25

comments.text: Honestly ya. The David Goggins of the world and all the weight lifters and body builders that push the message they do, have had just as much of a negative impact as sedentary lifestyle. Cuz all the ‚Äúsupermen‚Äù telling people to try to be them is the reason few people manage. You‚Äôll learn more going to the gym and talking to the old guy in average shape who‚Äôs been there for a while, rather than any muscle monster you see on the internet.
comments.author: @quintonb9626

comments.text: i get 15-20K steps everyday when i cut on top of my weightlifting, but when im bulking, why would i walk? ill need to eat even more, i literally can't, im stuffed
comments.author: @endorfiene7457

comments.text:
Ok, but what if no gym or too lazy to go to gym?

comments.text: For experts out there reading this, is this the best advice to follow to make sure I‚Äôm staying on track? If you could rate this video from 1-10, 10 being the best advice, please HIT ‚ÄòLIKE‚Äô on my comment. Thank you.

comments.text: I have a fitness plan for YouTube viewers.  Select a topic.   Mine is Months.  Any time someone says a month name during their video, I do 10 pushups.

comments.text: It's simple until you herniate a disc and there is no more fitness in your life. Since I herniated a disc I've been eating and sleeping for two years, waiting to heal.

comments.text: Back in April I had a dehydration episode that freaked me (and my family) out. In May I twisted an ankle in my 50th birthday, so I stopped working out altogether and now I'm in my all time max weight. 2025 is about to end now and this video completed my motivation. Thanks from CDMX.

comments.text: What you said is exactly what chatgpt said, you can have a toned body in 12 weeks just by what you and chatgpt said however it is toned and healthy not jacked like your body. Just fyi or just making sure people have realistic expectation.

comments.text: That gym is awesome; mine just upgraded after 15 years. I know it's my fault for not spending a high amount on a gym membership, but those North American gyms are top-notch.

comments.text:
This diet is much less about being and staying lean than it is about just feeling better, sleeping better, having a better immune system and not get sick as much. 

I've always been lean, but about a year ago switched to 80% whole foods, no added sugar, minimum seed oils and processed foods. My inflammation and back aches are gone (had 2 back surgeries), feel tons better, sleep rhythm is great, excess energy, put on muscle much easier, no mood swings, and my skin looks better. Went back to visit old friends this week and have already gotten several comments about looking younger and healthier. We all need to go back to basic ancestral foods without labels. Organic meat, eggs, fruit and vegetables, thats it. Get what you can from local farms and markets. Videos like this is the real deal guys, you can do it!
comments.author: @klatre

comments.text: Great video! I am 77 and have weight trained for 47 years. Not many people your age have the common sense and discipline that you have. I dont eat much red meat. Usually a grass fed 6 oz beef pattie once a week with a baked potato and a vegetable, usually broccoli. I eat mostly chicken and fish with veggies and or salad. Also 8 or 9 eggs a week and of course hydration, 2 to 3 litres a day. I am 5' 9"  170 pounds with 12 % body fat. I workout 3 days a week and play hockey one a week. It is so simple but not easy. I do take whey isolate once a day and creatine.
comments.author: @johnferguson5739

comments.text:
You look amazing.
And what you said about the ludicrous amount of YT videos, and all the nonsense about "new fads" and 100% contradicting "science" garbage,  <- Kudos for calling that out.
But that quality of food, not to mention the actual food itself, steaks, etc every day. And then on top its organic... That you are consuming every day.. must cost serious ¬£¬£¬£.
Also and Im not being sarcy, you must spend hours prepping, and cooking that food each day. Not everyone has the time, for work, "life" training, and all that cooking. Still a great video.
comments.author: @DaynJo

comments.text:
I've pretty much mimicked the diet you outlined here. I am only 7 days into this switch, but I gotta say, my appetite is totally manageable now - THANK YOU. I'm already feeling better and can feel my midsection tightening up just ever so slightly.

Have always been pretty good about hitting the gym, but have been stuck against the last 10% of my fatloss for a while now. Really interested to see where I'm at in another 5 weeks or so!
comments.author: @taylorsantangelo5228

comments.text:
Listen ive gone down from 230 to 190 with maybe going to the gym 3 times a month.
Cut your calorie intake to 10 cal per target weight
You wanna be 190 consume 1900 or less calories.

Cut majority of sugar, and fast 20:4
Its that simple. I have zero stretch marks, zero extra skin.

You have a 4 hour window to eat whatever minus processed sugar.

You dont have to cut carbs, you don‚Äôt have to go on some keto bullshit. 

Calories in and calories out is all it takes to lose weight period
comments.author: @DankestDM

comments.text:
yeah modern day bodybuilding sucks as it's all about drugs ,then you got all these influencers who are trying to confucius so you can buy their programs.

if you're a meat eater it's quite easy to build a lean body, just read books from 1940's to 1970's and your achieve more than you've ever done then following anything on the internet or modern bodybuilding
comments.author: @knightveg

comments.text: im about to unsub from every fitness guru ive found over 15 years and just sub to this guy... simple easy stuff that took me 15 years to realize on my own, through all the extraneous voices and opinions out there. this is the most no non-sense ive seen it.

comments.text:
I'm on the A2J program for commercial gyms - I defo recommend picking it up. Eric doesn't specifically include neck work or much direct forearm work in it, but I can understand why, people are super limited on time for the core programme.  Its sometimes tough to fit them in timewise, but I want to work on it.  For forearms, I've added reverse curls with the bar before squatting. I no longer get wrist pain from squatting now - I guess it helps warm them up beforehand. Also doing some deadhangs and getting a bit from deadlifting too. Few years ago I injured my shoulder and my neck defo took a hit due to deferred pain, have been rehabing for a long time. I chose to add one neck exercise to each session e.g. neck curls, neck extensions and rotations with a band. Amazing how weak my neck curls are, I can only do around 3 sets of 25 - not even adding weight to it yet! Interesting that Eric is doing a much lower rep range, maybe I'll work toward that.

Also surprising to hear Mentzer didn't think direct work was so necessary - I can't see how the neck itself, as opposed to your traps, would get hit much by compounds? Forearms sure, people often make that case, but still think its helpful.
comments.author: @benevans801

comments.text:
After following your advice for a month now and after having been spinning my wheels for two years with little or no gains to speak of, I just hit a PR today on flat dumbbell bench and am ready to progress next week. I'm finally starting to see the beginnings of  a difference in my physique. Thank you for setting it straight for me and cutting through the noise.
High intensity, simplicity, challenging lifts and failure.
Your recipe is one that is finally working for me.
I salute you sir.
comments.author: @Lamhfhad

comments.text: The weighted neck curl and reverse neck curl were staples of my training as a teenager in my basement and early days in the gym. But a herniated disc between C6-C7 prevents me from doing them. The neck muscles are critical especially now with all the forward head posture from cellphone use. The forearms are a different story. I've done wrist curls, had a homemade wrist roller I concocted as a teen. Built tremendous grip strength but the forearms just didn't grow. I'm genetically predisposed to small forearms.
comments.author: @firebird7479

comments.text: great vid,i have a question regarding mike mentzer routien so im doing a 3 workouts split around 10 days, Chest/back ,2 days rest,Legs,2 days rest,Shoudlers/arms, but i feel like im resting way too much and feel fully recovered after one day rest ,i did the split for 2 months or so and mastering failure and noting everything making progress ,also i would consider my self advanced been training for a while,what would you suggest ?
comments.author: @fouadhouassine3965

comments.text: Mf averaged to jack you have stated you started with 10 + weekly sets so you actually built your base and most muscle off the do how do we know your current methods are effective and not maintenance ?
comments.author: @mattc4266

comments.text: Any reason why you‚Äôve made an exception for neck and forearms workout when it came to your one/two sets to failure approach?
comments.author: @lclt55555

comments.text: At the gym now trying the neck thing for the very first time - I had no idea my neck was so weak! 5kg for 15 reps and I'm exhausted! What a trippy feeling though, feeling muscles I didn't even recognise before!
comments.author: @archangel_josh

comments.text: Could you make a video about warm-up sets? I‚Äôm a beginner and never really gave them much thought, but I feel like they become more important as you get stronger. If my rep range for an exercise is 6‚Äì8, is one warm-up set at about half the working weight for 6‚Äì8 reps enough? I‚Äôd love to hear your simplified take on it.
comments.author: @ady_kotidou

comments.text: Why 2-3 sets? And not one set to failure? I do them like that, like the rest of my body. One set
comments.author: @marcuso2006

comments.text: neck and forearms will be incorporated in my routine.üí™üèΩ
comments.author: @jakezaragoza6091

comments.text: Great video, so you are training neck and forearms twice per week on both upper days? Also for forearms I noticed a wrist roller in there, how do you like it? I'm guessing like neck, for forearms you would want to train both the wrist curl and reverse to hit both sides.
comments.author: @Cody_Trading

comments.text: Rock climbing will get your forearms looking huge too
comments.author: @Ricemachine88

comments.text: I've been tracking everything since the day I joined the gym 2 years ago. It's the best thing I could have done. Write down everything. Not just planning what workouts I'm gonna do but what I did so I'm not repeating unnecessary things too soon.
comments.author: @danielbotterill-wb6kq

comments.text: should I try and train my chest, back, shoulders and legs 1set per exercise?(3 Exercise per main muscle) . but What about the bi and tri, What about the abs?(Sub muscles in general). Please respond and Thanks a Ton!
comments.author: @MohamedBamkhrmah

comments.text: I train my neck with a resistance band for 7 months now, and have great results, it really becam thicker.
comments.author: @Greatburik3

comments.text: The first thing women notice about me is my bulging chest. I have to keep reminding these girls that my eyeballs are up here, not down there.
comments.author: @MiClLC

comments.text: Im torn between wether i should cut or bulk im 6foot2 198 pounds i have slightly less than 20 percent body fat i am 19 and have been lifting for 2 years
comments.author: @JosipGabela

comments.text: I told my wife to perform neck curles regularly beacause of the benefits we get from - now a days while everyone is looking constantly on their phone it is even more important

comments.text: Neck curl pain is diabolical yet effective as hell

comments.text:
Starting incline bench and military press was a real game changer for me. Flat bench never really developed my shoulders and upper chest.

Forearms were always naturally big, and my neck was slightly thicker than average hehe

comments.text: Your physique looks like young dorian's physique!

comments.text: Man I love neck training, my neck grew 3cm in only 3 weeks of doing 2 sets twice a week

comments.text:
You are one of the very few Fitness Youtubers not treating your audience like either complete iditots or aspiring pro bodybuilders. I think most of us (your audience) are neither of that. I, for example, just like to work out and/or get fit, look strong and be healthy. 

I don't want to be occupied with fitness 24/7 with the goal of looking like a Sci/Fi mutant from outer space, lol. And i couldn't care less if my workout plan isn't as optimal according to the newest released study. I also don't care to turn my life upside down and be totally fatigued, just to squeeze out 1.5% more gains.

I am not genetic gifted with superior recovery or athleticism in general, other than some youtubers who claim that fatigue management is just lazyness üòí. 
I need to be very careful with how much volume/Intensity i can put on my body. This is not coming from someone working out for a couple of months on and off. I train since 1994 and i realized over the years that (especially when you get older) the worst/stupid thing you can do (related to workouts at least) is to overtax your body. Because training without being fresh and accumulating more and more exhaustion (because you think you HAVE to soldier through this) doesn't get you anywhere. Eventually you HAVE to take  two or more weeks off, just to feel like a human again.

In the beginning i was trying to do super high volume workouts 6 times a week. And when my body became to tired (long before i made any progress) i didn't stop and gave my body the needed rest. No, i switched to another programm and the circle started again. Which was pretty stupid. But when everyone you read (there was no Youtube back then, only the magazines with articles about Workouts)  says you HAVE to do more and more and even more and then train harder and even harder next time, you never stop to learn to listen to your body. 
Heck, in the first 15 years, i had unlearned how it feels the train fresh and not tired. 

As you say all the time, Bodybuilding as a long-term undertaking. We as humans are so wired to think short term that it is hard to do something when the result is years in the future.  still need to restrain myself once in a whille when i work out so i don't go full out, balls to the wall and destroy myself in a workout.
I learned that the goal is NOT to train as hard as you can, but to train hard ENOUGH.
In my experience, right dosage of intensity, volume and rest time is the key. Not too much and not to little, do the RIGHT amount. The thing is most people who train to get strong/big do way too much. They often try to do workouts which where made by steroid users.

This is why i have unsubbed most of the Fitness Youtube channels i had for years, because i realized they either make videos for absolute beginners (train HARDER!!) or people who aim to be pro bodyybuilders (everything HAS to optimal on point.ALWAYS!!). 

I don't want to life like that and to be hones this is not fun anymore. 
I LOVE to train, it feels awesome and this is the only place where i feel peace and like a human (sounds funny, i know).
I train for 35 years and i would love to continue doing this for the next 35 years and more, if i am allowed to.

Sorry for the rant, i don't know why i wrote that much. Sorry for that.
comments.author: @nealsterling8151

comments.text: Babe, wake up. Eric uploaded a new video
comments.author: @fahiim_x

comments.text:
Key component here is be blessed with high test and lift in your 20s hard.  Try starting this same shit when you're 45 and you'll have a different experience. 

Lift hard, whether you go light or heavy, lift often and HARD, and do as much compound lifting as possible.  Bodybuilder lifting only gets results when you're juiced (frankly doing anything gets results when you're on gear), otherwise your stability muscle deficiencies will lead to injuries keeping you off the platforms.   The sixpack is made in the kitchen, not at the gym.  Anything else is absolute bullshit trying to sell you something.
comments.author: @Bushmills21

comments.text: Personally, I think it doesn't matter if you change your days etc. You're split. What's important is increasing the reps or the weight on any given exercise as long as you're doing that for your whole body. Your gold.
comments.author: @Explorshon123

comments.text: Bro as long as you are hitting some hard sets every week, it doesn‚Äôt matter how often you change your training program. Stimulus is stimulus.

comments.text:
Any idea on how to track certain "slow lifts" like lateral raises? I've been doing 17.5 kg for 12-15 reps for the last 2 months. I can do 20 reps but honestly im not convinced the form is similiar enough to the point where I can count it as valid progressive overload, unlike more "heavy" exercises like shoulder press, rows etc(basically the compounds)
Like how do u expect to progress on such a excericse where you've already reached a good weight I suppose, just expect to do the same weight?
comments.author: @JayzLegendz

comments.text:
Eric, regarding percentages, how much do you think the gains decrease if you compare frequency 1 with frequency 2? Because I'm going to start a PLP routine with only 6 sets per muscle group, and I don't know how much I'd be wasting my potential.

I heard that the minimum number of sets is 10, and if you do it twice a week it's even better. And this is a bit far from what I plan to do, which would be to train 3 days a week (it's not realistic to fit 10 sets per muscle group into one day).

I've been in and out of gyms for 20 years. Much more out. The results I've gotten could be achieved by anyone by being consistent for less than 2 years I reckon. 

So much wasted time.

comments.text: To be fair, you can only go so far in your training. I've been training since I was 14 (1978). If we had no physical or genetic limitations, I should be benching 3,000 lbs. and squatting 4,000 lbs. with 30 inch (0.76 m) arms and a lat spread wider than a condor. But, it doesn't happen that way. At some point the gains will stop and you will be in maintenance mode. That's just the way it is.

comments.text:
Excellent analysis! When I trained back in the late 70s and 80s, everyone in the gym was doing similar workouts because we all read the same magazines. We did what worked for the champions at that time. Here are the reasons why old-school bodybuilders looked better, including some that were mentioned:
1. Sunlight increased muscle tone. See the video "THE SUN CURE - Restoring The Lost Art of Light As Medicine"
2. Ribcage expansion work built large, Herculean thoraxes.
3. Serious, high-rep and set ab workouts, multiple times per week, made the waist muscles small, and tight. This made the shoulders look wider. The ab routine in Arnold's book "Education of a Bodybuilder" was 5 x 50 reps each for Incline Situps, Lying Leg Raises, and Broom-stick Twists.
4. Big calves! Standing, seated, and donkey calf raises, 5 X 15 reps, multiple times per week. 
5. Lats sweeping down all the way down to the waist from full-range (leaning WAY forward) cable rows and T-bar rows. Also barbell rows with the back parallel to the floor, standing on a block, letting the bar all the way down to the toes!
6. Stretching between sets making the muscles long and graceful looking, especially the lats and chest.
7. Wide grip chins behind-the-neck were very common. They stretch the ligaments of the shoulder blades, making for a wider front and rear lat spread.
8. Shorter rest periods with reps in the 8-12 range. When Arnold arrived from Europe at Gold's, he called it training "California Style" with only 1-min rest for smaller muscle groups like shoulder, arms, calves, and forearms; 1.5 min for chest, back and legs.
comments.author: @jimgurtner

comments.text:
It's because they didn't over complicate it. Old school guys here in our gyms are just every day men. Taxi drivers, construction worker, security guards, laborers yet they're the most jacked especially for their old age. They give the most ridiculous advise and programs.

But why are they still jacked and in shape?

Consistency. 

Most of these men only had access to one or two copies of  a bodybuilding magazine, most of them probably saw one or few training routines and just stick with it their entire lives, meanwhile most of us new lifters overcomplicate and get baited by the latest study the latest program our attention spans are too short.

And why were they so jacked despite having little to no equipment because they make the most out of it.

I've seen guys in poor gyms have better bodies that dudes who can afford commercial gyms. They train in scarcity, they make the best out of it. Meanwhile dudes in commercial gyms have wifis and are glues to their phones or too bored in their gyms they just try each equipment and hop from one machine to another.

I used to be this guy. Now I've seen the most progress by simplifying anything. Went full body 3x a week, 2-3 working sets 5-6 reps (if I can do 8 then I add weight until I can 5-6 reps max again)
comments.author: @Samson2323

comments.text: The editors of muscle mags only used the best artists , a time when meritocracy, talent and American culture mattered. The photographers didnt  just appreciate the beauty of the male aesthetic, they saw it as a symbol of the greatness of mankind. Specificaly the great men of the West who built the modern world. Their photographs  inspired young men to not develop their bodies for narcissistic pleasure but  to pursue greatness in everything they do. To build a world of prosperity and freedom for all. They inspired boys to see manhood as a time to prepare for, to get big and strong in order to serve  something greater than themselves,  to defend the weak, to build community, to defend country, to worship God. It was a time of patriarchy.   Today anyone with a phone can publishing photographs, usually focusing on crass, extreme fetish,  or overt narcissistic self worship and false idolotry. Today's images reflect the feminist destruction of patriarchy and their attack on men through systematic weakening and blurring the lines of gender roles. The feminization of everything has caused division and confusion rather than inclusion and unity. Matriarchy, the radical far left kind, seeks to destroy everything created by patriarchy, including  art and the portrayals of men in art.
comments.author: @GayBroBud

comments.text:
My reading of the science is this, and it's actually really simple: do enough volume, in an effective range of motion, with decent form, close enough to failure on every set.

I've been at this ten years, so I've had plenty of time to figure out what the "enough" is for me in each of those. Knowing what works for you and what you can recover from, is way more applicable to you than knowing the details of this or that niche exercise.

The basics get you 95%, the science makes that clear. Reasonable people can argue on optimising the last 5%, but until you get the 95% dialed in, don't worry about those last details.
comments.author: @Mikey__R

comments.text:
the thing is weightlifting from the 18th century to 1970's was CrossFit/Hyrox, kids in schools/gymnasiums were doing gymnastics jumping over wooden horses climbing ropes body weight exercises,Olympic lifting,powerlifting, strongman, kettlebell training flexibility cardio,boxing, wrestling, they did it all , they didn't just focus on bodybuilding, 

look at Arnold as a prime example  track and field/Olympic lifting/powerlifting/ bodybuilding, 

bodybuilding changed in the 80s all came down to being the biggest and leanest person on  stage and using as much drugs as possible, bodybuilding is much more easier nowadays so many machines people use and do not build real life strength like old lifers did

comments.text: 5‚Äô 10‚Äù 50 year old male here. I was tired of seeing the dad bod in the mirror every time I stepped in the shower. I went all in on the keto diet and dropped 85 pounds in less than a year. 245 lbs down to 160 in June of ‚Äò25.  That‚Äôs when I decide to start lifting. Bro from work gave me his old weight set and I added some adjustable dumbbells and a trap bar. Lift 3 times a week and I could tell when things wern‚Äôt right because I‚Äôd get fatigued quick or started hurting. Currently at 180 lbs and starting to see some muscle separation and veins in my arms.   Glad I stumbled across your channel. This advice hits home and is worth the sub  ü§ôüèªüí™üèª
comments.author: @bigshooter5912

comments.text:
2:54 don‚Äôt know if I agree about the ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt wanna train‚Äù because sometimes people get lazy. Sometimes you just don‚Äôt want to work out. The only time I would say that statement is true, is when you want to keep pushing through a set or keep pushing through a workout and your body actively tells you we need to stop.

So far in the gym, I‚Äôve been injured about 4 times in ten years:

1. Tore my right distal tendon, this was not from over training however, this was from curling my right arm supinated at the top end of the dead lift.
2. Tore my TFCC tendon in my right wrist, most likely under feeding, and because I torqued it when doing a straight bar, tricep push down
3. Tore my right rotator cuff. Again, this was not from over training. I used to flare my arms out whenever I was benching, I would not pinch my back and ensure that my shoulders stayed neutral.
4/4.5: not really an injury, but I got Hoffa‚Äòs fat pad impingement on my patella tendon, and it‚Äôs been going away, but that‚Äôs because I was sumo, squatting, and breaking parallel, so I was going way too far down with my knees way too out of track. Also, there‚Äôs been some small amount of pain on my hamstring tendon. On my left knee, but I‚Äôm pretty sure that‚Äôs because I started belt squatting, and I started using the bars and going way too deep into the squat to avoid breaking parallel by leaning back.

Which is causing too much stress on my hamstrings.
comments.author: @nathanielsings

comments.text:
I'm not super serious about my workout, I'm 34 and only started at the start of this year, mostly cause I was feeling unfit and my belly was growing, so I started with simple cardio, but then figured I'd also maybe work a bit on my looks so I can feel more comfortable with myself.
I ended up settling on a schedule where I do a 2 hour full body workout every Mon/Wed/Fri, the in betweens I just make sure I do like 7-12k steps a day, this way I get 48 hours of soft-rest between workouts and the weekends is full lazy mode.
This obviously isn't a very strict schedule, but I already can see a big difference compared to when I started at the beginning of this year.
The biggest things I'm struggling with is sleep, 4 years ago I entered a suicidal depression that I'm still dealing with and since then I can't sleep well nor long anymore, I usually only get 2-5 hours of good sleep a night, I can't get meds either cause one of my S-attempts was through overdose.
I feel like I could be doing better and more if I could sleep well, but alas.
At least working out gave me enough discipline to also be able to adjust my diet.
comments.author: @Xeonzs

comments.text: This adds to the overwhelming information as well, I‚Äôve been on a 6 day Arnold split for 3 years tracking my progressive overload and I‚Äôve never deloaded I‚Äôve never really known how, but I‚Äôm very also never had a serious injury. I‚Äôve know recovery and workout volume can vary based on genetics but I guess I‚Äôm overdue one?
comments.author: @BerialPhantom

comments.text:
It‚Äôs interesting that you talk about poor sleep messing with your ability to lift heavier, my dead lifts were at their peak when I was severely sleep, deprived, because I wasn‚Äôt on CPAP therapy. And now my deadlifts are moderate, it‚Äôs taking forever to get them up.        

Also, my squats were way more powerful before, so I don‚Äôt know if I agree with the sleep stuff I mean, it‚Äôs obvious that you have to get restorative sleep, but it seems to be contrary to me. I know eventually it would‚Äôve caught up to me, but.
comments.author: @nathanielsings

comments.text: So true. Was training 5-6 days a week and started incorporating kettle bell farmer walks. Messed my left forearm tendon bad & continued to lift thru it. Nagging injury for 4.5 months now. Currently taking BPC-157, TBC-500 to try and recover.
comments.author: @curtisking6271

comments.text:
Didnt follow this advice. 
3 bulging discs later, I still cant lift heavy without potential for pain. So im stuck at low weight for high reps for the forseable future. 

Dont be like me
comments.author: @TARDIS30001

comments.text:
Normally conventional training method states to do 6 to 8 weeks and then take one week off. That seems to be the sweet spot for me. The only times my lifts have been weaker or weights that were normally easy to lift, getting heavier, is whenever I was in an extreme deficit from fasting and still continuing to push just as hard.       

I was also doing HIIT, the same week I would do powerlifting, and you just can‚Äôt do both of those because it stresses your system too much.
comments.author: @nathanielsings

comments.text: For de loads, is it fine to lower the weight for some lifts (like 10-20 percent less weight than the working weight) and doing it 1-2 reps from failure? Also great videos man!
comments.author: @MatheeLeyva

comments.text: 1) Do full-body workouts 3x per week; 2) main compound lifts plus isolation exercises for smaller body-parts; 3) 3-5 sets of 15-20 reps at 7-10 RPE (increase weight/intensity if you surpass), 4) keep range of motion at 3/4 of the movement to protect joints and keep tension and pump; and 5) take a week to 10 days completely off every 4-6 weeks to allow satellite cells to donate to the muscle mitonuclei (i.e. De-Train week, Nucleus Overload).
comments.author: @panagenesis2695

comments.text: I got in to your channel at the right moment. Been loading my self with weight training and running for the consecutive 5 months with always increasing the weight and running distance. Ended up catching a cold like symptoms. I should have listened to my body and watch your video earlier üòÖ
comments.author: @pratamaendrawan3632

comments.text:
You deserve my subscription!
Thanks a lot bud, lately I have been feeling low I usually lift 170kgs easily bu this week i wasn't even able to lift 165 kgs and to add to the misery i am having a tricep tendonitis so I'll just get an week's off eat healthy in the meanwhile and yeah try to recover thanks for ur advice, appreciate it a lot
comments.author: @armedpixel6088

comments.text: Why don't you finish the set by reaching failure during the positive phase of the movement?

comments.text: Thing is if i dont work out just for 1 day for a rest day, i feel shit until the next day when i work out. Its even worse if it lasts the next day too. Working out just become a habit that i dont want to miss out

comments.text: You have made this same video 300 times bro. How about coming up with some different content

comments.text: "You're training too much" it don't feel like it skipped the gym a couple of times when i went back i realized how much in shape i was actually in full body is brutal got like 10 to 15 exercises each sessionüòÖüòÇ

comments.text: Something I found crazy is the training regime of one of the great Olympic lifters in the world. He trains hard twice a day. How he recovers from this volume is beyond me.

comments.text: Wait until you get old if you rest to much it's bad if you train to much it's bad and every year you lose strength no matter what.

comments.text: I did a cycle for the first and only time at 38 back in 2020. If anything, it really opened my eyes to how important recovery is. I take  a Mike Mentzer amount of rest now.

comments.text: Been training 6-7 days a week and more jacked than ever. Don‚Äôt listen to this guy. Hypertrophy is king.

comments.text:
Shout-out from Italy, bro! I used to be a ‚Äúmore is best‚Äù guy, but since I found your channel months ago, I‚Äôve been implementing your philosophy and have finally started to see huge gains in the gym. I‚Äôve been showing your content to all my friends, and they like it so much that they decided to switch to this kind of training.
Thank you so much bro, you trurly changed my life‚Äî keep it up!
comments.author: @davide.bbp04

comments.text: This is all excellent information. The most important take away I see is to get rid of the ultra processed foods. Frankly, it's not actually food. It's making you sick and it's highly addictive. That noted, a significant number of people may have to adopt a more "extreme" diet to get genuinely lean and strong. In my case, I consume a near zero carb diet - and it's been low carb for the last 9 years (and I kept the glycemic load of my meals low since 1999) because I and my immediate family tend to get insulin resistance and diabetes (both my brothers got type 2 diabetes in their late twenties). It keeps me lean and strong at 52 (32" waist and around 15% body fat without effort - I am NEVER hungry, and I have zero doubt I can cut to 10% if I wanted to without losing strength). I seriously doubt this would be possible for me on a high carb diet.
comments.author: @MarcosBuenijo1973

comments.text:
At the same time, I think its important to mention that this is a journey, and not a black and white thing of doing it right or not doing it right. Personally, I'm recovering from a very troubled upbringing. This makes that I don't have the motivation or means to meet every single requirement to get that dream physique. And frankly, I'm okay with this. I accept it, because asking from yourself that you do equally well as someone with a perfectly healthy upbringing is not realistic. You can strain and force yourself to be as good, but I dont believe that is healthy. Its better to improve over time, and overall in your life rather than to strain yourself in one domain like fitness.
I think this is relevant because I believe that many people who go into the fitness world are doing so to improve themselves, and only people who have trouble in their lives want to improve.
comments.author: @dirkheeres1265

comments.text: Going to start fasting again because of you. Also the tbsp of honey and walking more. Whenever I fasted in the past it was way easier to look leaner and feel better naturally. It makes the six pack more attainable when you don‚Äôt start eating until noon or so.
comments.author: @willusionist

comments.text: Bro I have all but given up on diets man they just don‚Äôt work. Caloric deficit is a joke unless I‚Äôm eating about as much as a toddler does a day. Decided to just try filling up on veggies and get 200g protein in a day not sure where the calories sit exactly, 1,100-1,500 maybe. I‚Äôll be full and satiated but the rest of my hair is probably going to fall out. Oh well. Tired of being fat and food is the enemy even if you eat healthy.
comments.author: @jaredk1989

comments.text:
not that easy look at peoples on the streets have many of them get it 001% hehe
you need to train abs hard for 2 years and have good diet and low bf
Many people can handle the training alone, but with a diet and low body fat it is very difficult
comments.author: @WiecznieNieNasycony

comments.text:
Quick question. Do you still progressive overload? What happens when you get to your goal body?

I know you're promoting getting a decent body for the average guy which i appreciate, but just wondered where to take it after 3, 5, 10 years once you get to a body youre happy with.
comments.author: @henrywrover2

comments.text: Do you keep track of your protein or try to get a gram per body weight or .8 grams or whatever they say now and days? Is that even important? Because I've ate clean and tracked everything and I'm like at 80ish grams of protein a day. Sometimes I can try to get more. Does that even matter if I'm just eating normal whole foods?
comments.author: @s3ktor1

comments.text: After watching your leg day workouts, i also removed squats from my routine, is it alright bro ? Like i do all the exercises you showed in that recent video you uploaded, + i do it in 2-3 sets. I'm at intermediate on my fitness journey. Kindly give some advice. ü§çü§ç
comments.author: @fahiim_x

comments.text: I hit routine 2/lower 1 for the gym this morning along with a few miles on the treadmill. I hit my 10k steps (minimum) for the day as I was walking out of the gym :) I'm doing your plan in conjunction with training for a 5K I have coming up in December.
comments.author: @Disguised_Dog

comments.text:
Great videos, keep going!

I see a lot of results after switching to it and also you videos helps a lot
