comments.text:
Im a bit confused, because you say you build your legs this way. But a few months ago you showed your leg routine, where you did multiple sets pr exercise. So, i am a bit confused as to which method you can contribute to your great legs. This, that you have done for a few months, or multiple sets that it seems you did for longer? Just curious, and i could be wrong about my observation :) 

Great video, thanks for the indepth video :)
comments.author: @kevin.-iq7oh

comments.text:
Am I the only one who tolerates very little volume in my legs? For example, I do hack squats, quad extensions, Romanian deadlifts, and hamstring curls, all 2 sets at a time

The pain lasts 4 days, so I can't do frequency 2. Is there a solution or at least an understanding of what's causing it?
comments.author: @Renekor

comments.text: I've been working out for over 10 years, with mixed results. I was a skinny guy like you. Since incorporating your advice into my training, my body finally started to change again. Within a few months, I've broken my personal records. I look and feel much stronger than ever! Big thank you for all your work and this channel.
comments.author: @JohnnyBadDi

comments.text: While I love the content of this channel, I have to say, alot of people will be misguided by your routine and current training philosphy. You objectively have an impressive physique and you say you've been in the gym for 10 plus years. Did you achieve these results training 3 days a week with only a handful of sets? Likely not. While hitting the gym 3 days a week can maintain your current physyque and muscle mass, beginners should not expect the same results on only 3 days a week in the gym.
comments.author: @willervilles

comments.text: I am a beginner I used to do really high volume with not even reaching close to failure like a month a ago, As I discovered your videos I have started to only do 2 hard  sets with a warm up set for each exercise. I train with push pull rest push pull legs. Idk if my spilt has too much volume for a beginner?
comments.author: @sleepstorm1192

comments.text:
Really appreciate the simple and very, very useful programs you show us.
No fancy, impractical show off exercises. Just the basics but they are done right!
comments.author: @nealsterling8151

comments.text: How do you feel about 3x/week full body rather than PPL? I find it‚Äôs more convenient because if I end up needing to miss a session for work, family, etc., I‚Äôm still about to hit full body at least once or twice a week. I‚Äôd definitely be interested in your thoughts on how to program that with lower volume and high intensity.
comments.author: @michaelputnam1017

comments.text: Bro what would you recommend for howlong each set is supposed to last with the 2 set per exercise. I'm a mid beginner, want to switch it from 3 to 2 sets per exercise for every single exercise I do. I just gotta know like how many seconds per rep, or the whole set is supposed to take. 1 minute rest for arms; 3 min rest for the bigger muscles; per set. I'll do like first set on every exercise as a start up and then the two following will be where i will go slow and go hard/heavy weight I can hold
comments.author: @TradingWithSergueev

comments.text:
You are fighting the good fight!
I always tell my friends that they do not need lots of volume, but they need to reach failure or close to it and progress load.
I wish more people understood it is that simple

comments.text: Man, I share this philosophy, but it's so cursed that basically one of the main points is pushing to failure, which my body just can't handle üò≠

comments.text: Recently found your channel and just snagged your program. I've been doing calisthenics/lifting for a few years now with good results, I but I figured I'd change it up. Just started the program this Monday so we'll see how it goes üí™

comments.text: Question: My legs have always been way more developed than my upper body. Is it a bad idea to only hit legs once if I‚Äôm doing 2 upper days?

comments.text: I do very similar, two sets of the exact four exercises you listed, plus two sets of Hack Squat (all to failure). Gets great results, takes about 50 mins.

comments.text: You don‚Äôt even need to be jacked to start reaping the benefits. I started training two years ago. Since then, I met my girlfriend at the gym, made friends, gained 20 kg, people treat me better because I look better, mental health, I feel great, and I‚Äôm just getting started

comments.text: whenever you see someone in shape you cant help but respect them

comments.text: Getting jacked made me avoid tooking pills to deal with my anxiety after a breakup with my ex. My therapist said: you've got two options go get some exercise or get some pills, and so did I. Whenever I felt bad, anxious or started thinking shit about the situation I'd simply dress up, hit the gym or walk for 30min. At first nothing happened, but then I started feeling calm and greater than ever, with the upside of getting like 10kg lean mass after this process.
comments.author: @JulioAzvdo

comments.text: I've talked to ripped people who spent years working out... they don't understand me, they believe everybody must hit the gym 4 times a week for almost 2 hours each time... I had been working out for two years, hitting the gym 4 days every week and spending an hour and a half... never accomplished anything... until now! Thanks for everything, man
comments.author: @Professor-Seba

comments.text:

comments.text:
"Being jacked is life's ultimate cheat code." I'm not sure what you mean with that to be honest. A cheat code in life can mean something completely different for everyone.

Heck, for my part i would be happy not being disabled. Just being normal would be more than enough. That would be MY ultimate cheat code in life. Being jacked would "just" be the icing on the cake, to be honest.üôÇ

comments.text:
Hey @averagetojacked, I found your channel recently and really like the approach. For context, I'm a 39 year old guy living in Switzerland who has been lifting for about 10 years. I'm 88kg (180cm in height) and fairly muscular - at least enough that people seem to remark on it when meeting me, etc.

The problem is, I have little kids now. My workout used to be 2 hours per day, 5 days per week. That's now impossible. I've slowly reduced the number of days per week, and number of sets per exercise slowly over the last few years (all before discovering your channel). I'm now at 3 sets per body exercise. So, 3 sets of incline bench, 3 sets of dips, etc etc. I ALWAYS go to failure, to the point where my form gives out and on some exercises I feel sick. I trust I'm really pushing it for each set.

However, my workouts are still a solid 1.5 hours, abeit now only 4 days per week. I arrive at the gym at 04:45 every morning so that I can finish before my kids wake up. But it's very very exhausting after several years of this, plus a full time job of course.

I started watching your content recently, and I would love to change to your method ‚Äî if only so that I could reduce wayyyy down on my workout times. However, if I'm really honest, I'm just scared that if I go down to ONE SET per exercise (üò±) I'm going to lose all the gains I've built up over the past 10 years.

Even if I just go down to 2 sets per exercise would save me so much time. I can't imagine doing 1 set per exercise.

Can you say anything to reassure me that it will work and I won't lose everything?
comments.author: @Monkey2ewok

comments.text: I think this advice can be harmful to those of us who barely got to 30% of our genetic potential and got stuck there. You can' be doing this until you are approaching elite. I very, very stubbornly decided to stick to Mike Mentzer's final (thinÔºâbook while at barely 30% of my genetic potential - for year and year and never progressed. That was working out legs every 4 to 5 days once. It does not work, you do not progress. I started seeing progress again when I started doing his split routine DAILY for 4-5 days in row and inserting 2 or 3 days off after. Those of us who barely have any muscle cannot get stronger with such infrequent single set 20 minute workouts IMO. I have no idea why Mike Mentzer didn't know this, I think because he NEVER would have trained someone who was a beginner, everyone he was dealing with had so much muscle mass they really did need the recovery days. I'm just saying this because I was off-track for about 5 years.
comments.author: @parasitius

comments.text: wait, what do we mean by "now?" science has been agreeing for years with minimalism. how many years has it been since jeff himself released his essentials program? and in recent years minimalistic training even has its own name now: the "minimum effective dose." i feel like people just see what they want to see and hear what they want to hear, which is new news that is also good news. but nothing is really new, and everything is quite good. i also feel like people are still somehow missing the point of the minimum effective dose, which is that a maximum effective dose must also exist. so, volume is still king. more is LITERALLY more. but less is more than enough, and more people are realising that enough is enough. that's what's really going on here imo
comments.author: @YeahTheDuckweed

comments.text:
I mean, Jeff is barely science-based to begin with but he just does something different for 3 months at a time to sell a new slop level program. You can just look back at his history/pipeline of "i tried x for x months - you can buy my program down below in the description". It's every time he releases a program. I'm sure hes a nice enough guy, but his content and programs are just slop thrown together using "science based" as a sales pitch. Jeff has a track record of interpreting data incorrectly and just running off of the most recent study shows "x result in x trainees". It's science for toddlers and beginners who don't understand what hes doing, because those people are easy to sell cheap shitty programs to.

Bro lifters worked this shit out decades ago
comments.author: @Tom-wk6pv

comments.text: Coming back from tearing both wrist/forearm tendons... 20 months later and I am VERY concerned about re aggravating and I am NOT doing anything HARD. Id rather slowly get to where I was before rather than lose all my gains like I did before! I tried to do more reps cause I was lifting light but going to failure re aggravated the right wrist/forearm! One week off hopefully I can still train! Starting again in two days!
comments.author: @DJDonkeytron

comments.text:
Here's my problem, the men with the best physiques, use like zero science and do all the stuff were told not to do, high volume high intensity train multiple times a week.... I have stopped trying to explain it with science, Ive stopped trying to rationalize
 it, if you want to get big train like you have a gun to your head. Ronnie one of the greatest BB of all time trained like a powerlifter, mike Mentzer would have beaten Arnold and took the title if he didn't let one loss get to him, train like a monster. Forget science forget what's in, JUST SHUT UP AND LIFT.
comments.author: @PrimarisDeiPrununs

comments.text:
@averagetojacked 100% agree on low volume. How do you maintain the intensity on a calorie deficit, though? Interested in your strategies.

Side note: with Wegovy / Ozempic becoming mainstream, there‚Äôs more people working out in deficits than ever before, yet they‚Äôre not getting enough protein, eating mostly hyperpalatable foods, etc. The answer is still ‚Äúdo it right‚Äù, but I am trying to figure out the best advice/strategies to keep our nation from all being skinny fat or giving up
comments.author: @prestondunlap8228

comments.text: Dorian yates has been telling you all since the 90s üòÇ
comments.author: @lordmac-b6v

comments.text: Started off about 2 years ago and was going 6 days a week. While it was fun and I was noticing results fast, the fatigue was just catching up to me. Now I‚Äôm on a 3 day PPL split and it‚Äôs such a breath of fresh air. I think we‚Äôre heading into a wave of fitness where less is truly more as long as you put in the effort each session and recover properly
comments.author: @zBatos

comments.text:
jeff is in it for the money
in 6 months he will release another program
remember lengthen partials? if they were so effective, why didnt he include them in this program as well? 
because all he does is pick a training style & make shit ton of money from the books
long live reddit
comments.author: @Luther7021

comments.text: Can you talk about how hard the sets should be ? Reps on reserve ? Sets to failure?  If I'm doing 3 sets of 8-10 reps how close to failure should each set be on different exercises?
comments.author: @jensammi

comments.text:
Intensity is everything. When I grind through the last two hard reps, I progress quickly. When I stop short of that I can stall out for weeks.

Your body needs a reason to grow and stopping the set within your comfort zone doesn't create a reason.

2 intense sets > 4 relaxed sets.
2 intense days per week > 4 easy days.
comments.author: @natanelarnson

comments.text: I don't know if I would say he "proved" anything. He has a new program, is a very experienced lifter, and needs a more balanced life. I don't think that level of intensity is possible for most people with less than several years of consistent working out.
comments.author: @Sa3vis

comments.text: What if you trained every day but focused on just one muscle group per session? For instance, hitting the chest only once a week or even once every 9‚Äì10 days. Would that approach fall under the idea of less is more?
comments.author: @martyhum6263

comments.text:
Been training exaclty like that for 21 years, and I still don't look like a bodybuilder. 

Too fat. But whenever I diet (correctly), I start losing strength, energy, size and the will to live.
comments.author: @ifstatementifstatement2704

comments.text: Why is everyone so excited to spend less time in the gym? The gym is the only place I feel alive. What do people do on the non gym days that‚Äôs so much better than working out?
comments.author: @jt23jt55jt

comments.text: Let's dont get this wrong tho... He is on a cut and he knows that he won't be gaining any muscle while cutting, this is why he is doing low volume. He still thinks you can up the volume as much as you can while bulking because it is easier to recover on a surplus.
comments.author: @alperbasiyor

comments.text:
I started doing these type of workout for 3 month now.

comments.text: So serious question with your style of training. You talk about the numbers going up and chasing prs and constantly looking at improving the weight but are your muscles growing ?? Most guys who want to get in shape and get a better body aren‚Äôt trying to improve numbers there trying to improve what they see in the mirror. You have shown pics before and other people have commented on the fact you don‚Äôt look any bigger. So is your physique staying the same due to muscle memory and some stimulus it‚Äôs getting but your numbers are going up ?? That sounds more like strength based training rather than hypertrophy. This isn‚Äôt an insult or taking shots at you am genuinely just baffled with how much conflicting advice there seems to be. A lot of people are promoting low volume training now a days but the thing is nobody who is promoting it built there body doing that style of training so what is the answer. I couldn‚Äôt really care about the numbers I want to look in the mirror and feel happy with what I see and have a muscular physique
comments.author: @jamesgoodwin5360

comments.text: would love to see a full workout video to see how you train especially to failure and how it should look like
comments.author: @syntrixlive7466

comments.text: Do you experience joint pain when going heavy? because i have tried both styles of training and when going heavy with few sets my joints just seem to take a beating and limit my training, so is it still possible to get the same results with higher reps and a little lower weight?
comments.author: @niklasrelund4223

comments.text: Damn I love your videos. Today is Saturday. I don't workout on weekends but after this video, I'm so motivated, but I'll fight the urge. The other motivational videos from other people are exhausting and confusing just from watching them. Thank you for another no bs, straight forward and simple video
comments.author: @domjohndemarco

comments.text: I'm 61 and have been training since the age of 14. There will a point in time where will you look the same. There's only so far you can go physically in size and in strength. At some point in your life, the injuries will catch up with you, and you will end up training lighter.
comments.author: @firebird7479

comments.text: I wonder if you had any advice for people (like me) with diastasis recti (separation of the abs / linen middle).  I would like to have more abs but looks like doing the regular crunches are not indicated.  I do understand some body builders have this condition precisely due to the exercising, I wonder what exercises they can do for their abs.
comments.author: @Raist3db

comments.text: I went from 6 days a week to training once a year. The results are amazing.
comments.author: @WilliamHudson-ug7wz

comments.text:
It works. I‚Äôve been doing Mentzers ideal routine for some months now. Growth and strength has exploded. If you‚Äôre unsure, just try it. My life quality is so much better. Didn‚Äôt realize how fatigued I felt most of the time because I trained so much.

Now I have free time outside of the gym, and the energy to enjoy it.
comments.author: @commanderkeen2078

comments.text: After 10 years with periods of working out 7 days a week at 20 sets, you've reached close to your physical maximum naturally and built a solid foundation.. what is your progression like these days? Because maintaining only takes one set to failure per week. "Do what got me here not what I'm doing now, it's literally just an experiment" so this advice is for advanced lifters?
comments.author: @r34ct4

comments.text: I did the whole volume thing and barely look like I lifted, after a few years. Last year January I started training to failure, one set with additional dropsets, push pull legs. Each workout repeated within 7 days after the last workout. So if I did a push day, I'd have the next push day within 7 days. That's high intensity, little volume. I gained strength and lean mass while on a cut. Shows how bad my workouts must have been before
comments.author: @tonypaella

comments.text: Hi there, I really enjoy your content. Cutting back my training sessions from 6-7 days to 3-4 has been a gamer changer. I used to deal with really bad joint pain and inflammation in addition to not making much progress with my lifts. Initially, its hard because more is always thought to be better but honestly less is really more in this case. You'll never realize what overtraining is until you take a step back and actually heal properly and rest properly.
comments.author: @cole6383

comments.text:
Question in a built in contradiction here:
You want less sets, just pushed to max intensity/failure, but you then mention to only progress weight when all 3 sets hit the target rep (say 10 reps). But waiting until you hit 10 reps for all sets inherently means the first two sets were not intense enough or to failure?? I don‚Äôt get it.
comments.author: @SpaceKraft24

comments.text: If anyone is familiar with Mindpump podcasts and channel, it wasn't until I found them about 4yrs ago that I finally got Amazing results after YEARS of overtraining and not knowing it. Most of their programs are 3 days a week when I was doing 5 to 6 with a very active job. And I never really made progress until I went to 3 days
comments.author: @backintogear9071

comments.text: Question. Someone probably already asked. But if you so strongly believe that 1 set is enough. Why do you then do incline DB press(*chest+triceps*) chest flyes(*chest*) and tricep extensions(*triceps*) you still train the muscle twice. hell the triceps is also trained with shoulder presses! So is it 1 set? 2 sets? or 3 sets? Dont mean to be a dick, but it just contradicts what you say. Love to understand what you mean. Thanks!
comments.author: @KillmWillemTube

comments.text:
''Once you stimulate a muscle with complete failure, why would you want to stimulate it more''

Does this mean you don't need more than one set per exercise/muscle per session provided you go to failure with it?

EDIT: never mind, the answer (probably, but not proven) is in the rest of the video
comments.author: @BcroG11

comments.text:
For decades my training was: MON: Chest/Shoulders/Triceps; WED: Back/Biceps; FRI: Legs/Abs. 9 sets per body part except arms -- 6 sets each for biceps and triceps (my  best bodypart, no need to train them more than I do). Now I do a 4 day split, same set up, rotating days as I train at 2 different gyms, one of which is only Saturday evenings.

I bike ride 4X week for 40 minutes. I'm 61 and have been training since I was 14. My training philosophy falls in line with Mike Mentzer, Steve Reeves and Lee Labrada.
comments.author: @firebird7479

comments.text: You don't even have to go to absolute failure.  Leave 1 rep in the tank and complete that final rep.  Progression is most important over time.  If you go from 185 on Bench for 8 reps and a few years later get 225 for 8.  You will look bigger if you eat in a surplus
comments.author: @petercalicchio4973

comments.text:
I understand giving advice about getting jacked but you‚Äôre using evidence based off the present - i.e you‚Äôre already jacked and are maintaining. 

If someone is just starting off, they‚Äôre a noob or a beginner, do you think following your current advice would work? For me, it seems the information and advice of the split and diets that got you from beginner to advanced would be more beneficial to beginners.
comments.author: @Elbow1878

comments.text: Isn't there a biais to say less training is more efficient when you already trained during years and years before? I agree with the part saying you don't need 2h session but if you can do PPL twice a week wouldn't you have better result than just once?
comments.author: @vivalabello

comments.text:
I'm currently taking a break from lifting and focusing on rehabbing my body with restorative training. It's definitely minimalist in nature, but I feel surprisingly good. üíØ 

1) 3x per week : 4 sets each of strict feet elevated pushups, walking lunges for distance, and strict pullups. 

2) 3x per week : 15% max incline walking for 30 min, not holding onto the treadmill. 

3) Dog walking outdoors for 10-15K steps daily of general activity.
comments.author: @ryandeffley7652

comments.text:
Love the Mike Mentzer reference. Though, I think we have studies now that clarify the relationship between volume and growth.
I agree that alot of people don't approach their training with any type of intensity, but personally, I still recommend 2 sets minimum per exercise- the extra set is for added volume- which can lead to growth. 
Still, love the video
comments.author: @Raey_Thoven

comments.text: What is your opinion on a PPL vs UppLowUpp split if you workout on the same exact 3 days a week? (in my case monday, wednesday, friday). With a normal PPL split there's 7 days between each muscle group, but with UppLowUpp there will be 3-5 days between each muscle group. Except for legs, but I also go for runs 1-2 times a week so I don't wanna go too crazy on the legs.
comments.author: @helpfulonline

comments.text: I can't feel flys in my chest... they just hurt my shoulders
comments.author: @dillonkeller4477

comments.text: 41 and i do 2 sets to failure 4x a week targetting each muscle group twice with different exercises and I've never been happier with the results and working out does not feel like a chore anymore
comments.author: @Noid1220

comments.text: Interesting video. I recently started thinking about changing my schedule a bit. I currently do 3 workouts per week at the gym, and I can't add more. At the moment I do upper, lower, upper, but I want to try push, legs pull.
comments.author: @simonchris5426

comments.text: Thanks for this, changing my traning program starting next week. Gonna lower sets per muszle group. Was thinking about it long time ago, using Bukgarian Split Squats as example. My legs are fried after roughly 3 sets per leg, so why would be any diffrent for other muscles
comments.author: @Big_Daddy953

comments.text:
I am doing full body 3x a week, around 6 sets per muscle besides hamstring and chest which I only do 4 set a week. Feeling fresh every workout. Feels like you get much more out of every workout.

I am doing full body because I like the higher frequency better.
comments.author: @mattricav

comments.text: If i go to the gym 2x a week will this still work pushing to failure 1 to 3 reps?
comments.author: @calebwalker7619

comments.text:
Hi from uk great vlog 
I also use a three day split but run it as PLP to keep the two upper further apart to help recovery  all  one top set to failure  works well for me
comments.author: @Leonard-kd7uj

comments.text: I've been dabbling with full body routines. Do you have any insight into those? I've been doing mostly 5 day higher frequency full body but everywhere I'm reading if you're over 40 I should be doing 2-3 full body instead.
comments.author: @bastinelli443

comments.text: Could you tell us how many sets you do every bodypart every week? Thanks!
comments.author: @XplicitEnergy

comments.text:
I have been doing plp with 3 sets per exercise, 3 days a week
And now my body have more definition than when i do the oldschool (20set/week)
And recovery feels better :D
comments.author: @marshalandreas3947

comments.text: It helps my anxiety to do 4-5x week. Depending on gym programming. I go hard on the first 3 splits and deload by half on the other days or do boxing cardio.
comments.author: @kanshou

comments.text: Bro this is a breath of fresh air! Everyone's trying to eek out 1% as if they are living in a lab. I get it, you put so much time and effort in, why not optimise, But like you said, unless you are trying to get on stage, lifting hard and eating well will get you most of the way.
comments.author: @randallbroughton8011

comments.text: did u build ur physique on this or on a high volume program?
comments.author: @jonrod7990

comments.text: Would you say that this type of training is suited more for experienced lifters over newbies or is it optimal for all levels?
comments.author: @stipeskugor5020

comments.text: So if 1 series per part is enough why you are doing 2 excercises for chest? Its 2 series in the end :D
comments.author: @mditrich

comments.text: I go all out on my sets and i have tried the 1 set system and no matter what two-three sets produces better results for me.
comments.author: @whydoyouneedmyname6508

comments.text: Contually progressing forever is impossible. At some point in your life you will begin to regress. That age will be different for everyone. Train hard and listen to your body. Diet and rest are key.
comments.author: @ebowalker571

comments.text:
I've made a very similar experience with my own routine.
It's efficient and flexible, focusing on accessible basic exercises so I never have to wait for equipment.
Upper Body (2x/week):
Exercises: Dips, pull-ups, incline barbell press, barbell row, biceps, triceps, and lateral raises (2-3 sets each).
Variation: I just alternate starting with chest or back.
Lower Body:
A simple HIIT circuit, optimized for my running routine (which I've been doing for 1.5 years).
My philosophy: I might leave 5% of potential gains on the table, but I prioritize efficiency, accessibility in any gym, and simplicity. No fancy stuff needed.
comments.author: @edem3655

comments.text:
I like your content but I‚Äôm sorry, you cannot both hit the top of your target rep range for a given weight for 3 sets AND train near failure each set. If you‚Äôre hitting the top of your rep range all 3 sets, then the first two sets weren‚Äôt near failure.
Unless I‚Äôm completely missing what you‚Äôre saying? Please clarify.
comments.author: @SpaceKraft24

comments.text:
A question from someone who has intermediate level knowledge and beginner level physique.

How do you know when your tendons and ligaments and joints are ready for almost linear progressive overloading?

 For example after almost a year long break, I'm doing a 15 to 20 rep sets (1 rep in reserve), to get back in habit, consistency and cardio state and leave my tendons enough time to get used to moving. 
I'm thinking of doing this for a month. 

Any other advice from people who have had bad luck with ligament/tendon injuries like I'm prone to tennis elbow?
comments.author: @SakshamSharma-tr9fk

comments.text: Looks like Lyle McDonalds GBR. Excellent routine brother. Keep on making those gains üëä
comments.author: @MGTOW-x1z

comments.text: Fantastic stuff! I love how you give a very clear & simple (!!) guide for what to program and how to progress. Came here looking for some confirmation on if I'm training in a way that actually works and was very pleased to find almost the exact same program I'm running!
comments.author: @emuliusv

comments.text:
Hi cool video.

A little confused tho. It doesnt really make sense that you end by saying that you made sure to get minimum 10 sets pr muscle group pr week? You previously 
 said that isolation exercises like biceps/triceps fx was 2 sets pr upper day, i.e 4 sets or week. Can you elaborate?
comments.author: @Joshua-uq9zw

comments.text: I‚Äôve been doing upper lower split for a few months and already seen rly good progress, but anytime someone shows their upper workout the arms always get 1 exercise for 2 sets. While it‚Äôs good for time management I often question if adding a 2nd bicep/tricep exercise (e.g. preacher + hammer curl) would be beneficial or not and why?
comments.author: @Ethereal-i1z

comments.text: In my 40s now and tried every training their is and im not a fan of this 2x a week as a natural, my best gains has always been hitting everything 1x week and it's what ive just gone back to, listen to top level naturals and how they trained nearly all did 1x a week and got the best results doing 1x a week, look up the channel Longevity muscle it's full of interviews with natural champions and competitors
comments.author: @robbo8074

comments.text: I am training for like 2 and half years what should you recommend focus more on eccentric or concentric just drop that you do or control in full range of motion with TUT in every isolation exercises or compound too like you do with shoulder press and. Latpulldown and biceps curls?
comments.author: @1v4xGyroGODZzzz

comments.text: Eric thank you for all you share, question I believe you follow a 3 day week training of push, legs, pull ?  What is the difference between PLP and the 4 day week program of 2 upper days and 2 lower days?   I appreciate your knowledge and time üôè. J
comments.author: @jeremyolds4800

comments.text: I feel like waiting to hit all the sets for same reps is a bit counter-productive. If i am able to hit my 3rd set for 10 reps, then i definitely could have hit my first set for 10+, which makes me feel like I'm slacking off a bit. Also i feel like adding one more exercise for shoulders and an exercise for glutes would be also beneficial, those muscles are deceivingly big.
comments.author: @The.Joni.

comments.text: Hello maybe my maths is wrong but if for example I do 2 sets of triceps like a push down or dip, and I do upper twice a week doesn‚Äôt that mean I only do 4 sets of it? even with 3 sets it would me 6 sets a week for triceps. I may be wrong but this is literally just what my brain is telling me.
comments.author: @ahknasrr

comments.text: After watching your upper/lower suggestion video i started working on it, but after some i noticed that, I've been pushing it too hard that my body was not recovering properly, i started felling sick every week. So form this week , I've started a 5 day split,1) Push-(chest, tricep, shoulder).2) Pull-(Back, biceps). 3)Leg&Abs . 4) Upper. 5) Lower
comments.author: @udayshankaruday7163

comments.text: How long did his training sessions usually last?
comments.author: @kelvincarlos4632

comments.text: The upper lower seems perfect for 4x/week
comments.author: @NoONE-bk7ud

comments.text: When you say a certain amount of sets per muscle group does that mean the upper part of the UL split or does that mean a certain amount of sets for lets say biceps?
comments.author: @Connor_7676

comments.text: Idk seams difficult to get in 12-16 sets per body part a week with this, and even if you do manage to split it up where it works, rest just isn‚Äôt there. Plus you have to slack with the volume and intensity, just for frequency‚Äôs
comments.author: @WhyandAyeWhy

comments.text:
hey bro, Great video.

I am new to the gym & I want to start working out using your split how many sets should I do for each exercise and at what rep ranges?  

thanks
comments.author: @theMadZakuPilot

comments.text: Just curious, why is a simple thing like bench press not included?  I know there is the include dumbbell press, but why is a normal bench press not in there?
comments.author: @2356Vincent

comments.text: Thoughts on doing this program but only with 1 set instead of 2? I have been lifting for a while
comments.author: @MarkusLienY

comments.text: Is this upper lower split for beginners in your paid program as well?
comments.author: @Ricemachine88

comments.text: What lut do you use ? Are you just shooting in log and playing with curves, saturation, and contrast?
comments.author: @ItzGlxw

comments.text: Would it make sense to alternate between U/L and PPL to build that solid base? Like 1 week U/L, 1 week PPL?
comments.author: @zanvoglar8269

comments.text: So do you do straight sets ? Pyramid ? Reverse pyramid?
comments.author: @timothyhergert4199

comments.text: 3:03 wouldn't it make more sense to do 2 sets for compounds because they are more fatiguing and 3 sets for isolations because they are more focused on an individual muscle
comments.author: @dinodude3252

comments.text: One doubt eric, no specific work for glutes & adductors on lower days?
comments.author: @Marcos-qe4qm

comments.text: Just good solid advice, awesome video. Been doing something similiar for a year now and it works.
comments.author: @Vinaigre

comments.text: Can i do 2 days a week? Upper lower? Or it has to be 4 days.

comments.text: i have a question how many should i lift weight? heavy? or normal or light

comments.text: Question man, are 4 sets a week for isolation workouts enough? For example tris and biceps?

comments.text: What do you think about training push pull legs every 4 days? One bodypart every 12 days

comments.text: Brother, a piece of advice you didn't ask for, if you'll allow me, but please work on your thumbnails, I can't distinguish your last 5 videos from each other.
comments.author: @GrEaTDemOnBlade

comments.text: I feel the same way. Year 8 of lifting and I'm finding that intensity truly outweighs volume now. 6-10 sets per week is perfect.
comments.author: @barbellbryce

comments.text:
Hey man
Can you help me with a mindset issue?
So I started off really fat at 90kg, over the last 2 years I've dropped weight to 62kg, I'm lean, have veins everywhere, have abs
And I look like i lift atleast in clothes which fit and people often complement me on my looks.
However even though I've accomplished my initial goal , I now wanna bulk and gain some more muscles( wanna bump my 13.5 inch arms lean to 15 inch etc). But as someone who started overweight im having a  complex over gaining weight.
Any advice?
Btw I posted the same in your q/a post 6 days ago, doing it here again so u might see it
comments.author: @JayzLegendz

comments.text: I really like your videos. I agree that you dont need alot of training etc but its one thing that you forgot. Its your gene to build muscles. You look enhanced seriously and i think i am not the only one hur thinks that. But i am sure that you of course dont take anything. You are to smart for that. I have workout for 8 years but i am not nearly that ripped that you are and no way near to have that muscle size you have. And so, what i am saying you have way better genes then many in here. So just eat right train and sleep well its not a guarantee that you will get ripped if you have bad genes.
comments.author: @validus5808

comments.text:
You're biggest fan here. Just want to make sure I'm doing this correctly. 

Mike mentzer workout: 2 or 3 lite weight warm-up sets, then 1 set 6 to 10 reps to failure 

Your 3x8-12 workout: just a little warmup with bands before lifting and a little treadmill, then the 3x8-12 

Is that correct?
comments.author: @domjohndemarco

comments.text:
1 set to failure. 2-3 minutes rest. Warmups in treadmill for 5 mins. Usually does 2-3 warm up sets for first exercise and the. 1 warmup for the rest
1:02 Incline DB Bench Press
1:42 Incline Machine Flys
2:48 Shoulder press (DB, or barbell)
3:11 Lateral Raises
4:12 Tricep Pushdowns (or overhead extension)
comments.author: @nikoa100

comments.text: So you do this one workout once a week in a 3 day PPL split? If you train higher volume such as 3 sets on the push day per exercise is it okay to go to failure on all 3 sets? Or will increase injury chances?
comments.author: @akulranjan3734

comments.text: I've been doing this type of training for years, and when i tell someone that's all excesses i do, they laugh. High volume training used to make me fatigued and exhausted for the next day with life, work, etc i lowered down my volume, increased rest days, thinking something was better than nothing, but surprisingly, i made more gains
comments.author: @Just.A.Guy.On.Internet123

comments.text: Hey my man! I am 47, Dad of 3, former pro athlete, football and track coach! In my personal training I have used your philosophy for years, so I agree 100% with the method and enjoy the content! Quick question for you‚Ä¶ rest in between your sets.. which do you prefer? I feel comfortable around 90-120 seconds between working sets.. thoughts?
comments.author: @CoachSlice_GoGovs

comments.text:
I find your Training Style and Plan is good.
The Problem is YouTube Fitness is Just black and White.
High Volume or Low Volume.
I think the best is medium Volume.
I also did low Volume got stronger but this is Just because your fatigue is lower and you get a new Set Point.
I Got a little Bit flat on Low Volume.
So i so 2 exercises 3 Sets per muscle 2 times a week.
Im full getting stronger but got enougth Volume to get a Pump and fullnes in the mirror.
comments.author: @djjankov6667

comments.text: What timing - I just finished your push workout from your personal PLP plan. Only issue I had was that my gym doesn't have a chest fly machine, so I did cable flys instead. For lateral raises, I use cables for behind the back lateral raises or I lean against a wall and use dumbbells at an angle.

comments.text: eat a small 200 calorie surplus, eat 180g protein, sleep 8 hours a night and track your lifts aiming to add either a rep or weight each week. Also track weight so you are gaining 2lbs/1kg of weight a month...do that form 8 months and boom easy..youtube fitness overcomplicates things so much at this point. love the channel man!
comments.author: @Rakyr

comments.text:
Guilty of not properly tracking my weights & reps. As I'm very new to the gym, there's a lot of things I need to grasp with my brain power which makes things a bit overwhelming. But I think tracking with a notebook would actually help a lot.

One thing tho which I don't understand that how do I actually measure my progress. Like when I hit the first machine of the day, I'm at my max. But down the road I get more & more exhausted with each machine even after rest (hopefully that's normal) so I can't hit the max of my potential which I could've if I hit that machine first. Hopefully I've been able to explain that a bit. How do I know what's my max on a particular machine. Should I switch my first machine in every PPL session unit I get my maxes in all the machines?
comments.author: @koush_b

comments.text: I definitely agree with this.  I started using an app about 2 months ago (Strong) and it has made a big difference in how focused and intense my workouts are, for the very reason you describe in this video.
comments.author: @brianwolfe9472

comments.text: Bro, I deadlift and squat now but I‚Äôm using how to program these in. Same day too fatiguing but then i do legs then chest and back the next day so there would be too much overlap. What should I do please? Thanks
comments.author: @Williamsen10

comments.text: Has your stance on kink body‚Äôs approach changed now that your only doing one hard set to failure?
comments.author: @JordanHearne-h2g

comments.text:
Hey Eric.
Just new to your channel and I love how real and authentic you are.
Random question and I think I know the answer but here goes.
Do you consume alcohol?

comments.text: yeah really recognise this, i've been lost and just repeating workouts and not making progression. Although i get jacked quick, i can get much more out of it.

comments.text: can you do more vedios on fat loss , this is a dark place where you dnt have hope , people tease for trying , and the non changing weight scale , altogether it seems impossible , then it becomes emotional eating

comments.text: Hey man, do you also run as part of your routine, as you mentioned longevity? Thanks for the content btw.
comments.author: @harishkumar-iv2jo

comments.text: Love watching your vids pre gym. It just grounds me and reminds me to keep things simple when i get there.

comments.text: PLEASE DON'T CHANGE A THING! I heard you talk about others saying your videos are repetitive. I LOVE YOUR VIDEOS! Repetitive or not, they're simple and to the point. Thanks to your magical phrase, compliment not consume, I changed my workouts to what you do. I'm 47, worked out over 30 years. 2 hours in the gym. Got results and it was fun but now seeing your routine, I changed mine to yours. I'm happier now, I have more time for other things, I feel great. Please don't change anything. If it ain't broke don't fix it. They don't like it, they can watch another person. My only request, not a complaint, is can you show us your ab routine and talk about sets and reps? Thank you again. You're genuine, not another telling us they discovered some new way of exercising. Simple, enjoyable, more time for other things, I look forward to the next workout instead of being tired and dreading it. Thanks again man!
comments.author: @domjohndemarco

comments.text: I found Mike Mentzer when I was around 20 years of age. The Heavy Duty training program he had at the time was brutal. Very few people could stick to it, not because of the physical aspect, but the mental aspect. The first time you train, the feeling coming out of the gym is great, but the next time you go in, it's "Oh, crap, I gotta do this again?" I found that Lee Labrada's training worked best for me -- 3 exercises, 2 sets each, 6-8 reps, 1 minute rest between sets. For back he trained 3 sets per exercise. 2 day split/4 days per week. I found it to be a hybrid between Mike Mentzer and Steve Reeves with the intensity to match.
comments.author: @firebird7479

comments.text: I'm  63 I've been training a long time, and I absolutely love your content. Since watching your channel, i started doing a three day split. The only difference is I put my leg day in the middle. I'm a big Dorian Yates fan, so I like this three day split approach. I also think you're spot on by saying if someone is just staring to do more sets to train the movement.  I like there no drama on your channel, just practical fitness advice. Thanks for sharing ‚ù§
comments.author: @samwright738

comments.text:
Pull Day
Warm up
5m on treadmill
Band circuit. Lat raises, overhand press, curls, face pulls (2-3 sets)

Routine 2-3m rest even for warmups, 8-12 reps then progressive overload
Wide Grip Pulldown (2-3 ramping sets), 1 to Failure
Chest Supported Row 1 warmup, 1 to Failure
Reverse Pec Deck 1 warmup, 1 to Failure 
Cable Reverse Fly 1 w, 1 to failure
One Arm Cable Curls or Curls on incline 1 w, 1 to Failure
comments.author: @nikoa100

comments.text:
Dope video! Big props to you for actually listening to the followers instead of being defensive like so many others would do! Great video and thank you bro :) !

And honestly you're so right - yeah, perhaps this or that will "maximise" your potential, and add 0.2 inches to your arms a year, but so what? Do what you enjoy man.. That way consistency follows.

Btw im all for people experimenting in gym , but wtf is the guy in the back at 05.02 doing

Please help me with a 3 day structure routine I know you have yours and sadly I can‚Äôt get it now. But hopefully you can drop it soon.

comments.text: Thanks to your A2J program I've been able to improve each workout I've done; I shut my brain off when I'm in the gym, focusing only on beating the logbook and myself of the previous week. I'm also working in improving both my eating habits and my sleep. Looking forward to the Legs and Push video update!
comments.author: @marcosilviomonti

comments.text: Bro please can you tell me why I‚Äôm sore for so many days? I do low volume. For example, chest 4 sets and it‚Äôs so sore all week. Yes I take every set to failure but it‚Äôs so annoying - lean bulking and everything is genuinely on point c sleep, nutrition, mental health. No idea what I can do: ectomorph body type
comments.author: @Williamsen10

comments.text: I‚Äôm 56, I‚Äôm a lot older but you‚Äôre a wise man!! Everybody these days are trying to make everything complex, data driven by the nano win. You my friend are the best example of repetitious reinforcement. I‚Äôd rather hear the same continuous message every day, rather than a new twist just for micro wins, ego and originality. Your evidence says it all. Keep it going, best regards from Liverpool England. Just subscribed, looking forward to the same messages ;0)
comments.author: @eddiefox7

comments.text:
Dig the content, man ‚Äî straight to the point and no BS. Quick question about your off-day setup: if your three-day split is Mon/Wed/Fri, are you just doing cardio on the off days and taking weekends completely off?

I‚Äôm getting back into training and want something simple to follow, because I tend to overcomplicate things and fall off.

Thanks.
comments.author: @chriscmbv

comments.text: I'm 61 years old and have been training since I was 14. My philosophy has been simple: Train as heavy as you can, for as many reps as you can, with the best form that you can. When your form suffers, you're set is done. How man reps, how much weight and how many sets is relative to the individual.

You are basically doing rest pause sets, not a single set to failure

comments.text: This whole video was me to a T. About 4 months ago I decided to focus on big compound lifts and stick to them no matter how much my brain tells me to switch things up. I also stopped listening to 90% of the content I was previously. Yes, a few gains physically, but the mental feels so much better and is the real win. Appreciate your words.
comments.author: @tanman4441

comments.text:
Mate your videos are fine but it seems that you talk the exact same thing over and over and over again. Come on, give us some actual advice, tell us how you train, how failure feels, how your chest program looks like, how your warm ups and stuff. Like, zoom in on what you do, instead of overviews only. 
Cheers :)
comments.author: @kevin.-iq7oh

comments.text:
I've been watching your videos for a while now and I wanted to get your opinion. Since I‚Äôve been inconsistent with the gym for the past 5+ years but recently got more disciplined, would it be smarter for me to follow your 3-day routine? I feel like it‚Äôs different for me since you already have a lot of muscle and I‚Äôm still skinny fat. Wouldn‚Äôt it be better for me to train 4 times a week instead ‚Äî with Day 1 as chest + triceps, Day 2 as back + biceps, Day 3 as legs, and Day 4 as shoulders?

I just want to stop feeling so bad about myself, feel more confident and finally get success with making friends and meeting women.
comments.author: @TradingWithSergueev

comments.text:
This is good stuff man. 

I too was tossed to and fro from fitness influencer to fitness influencer. One would say this and one would say that. It left me confused. Once I found out what worked for me and what contributed to my strength and my growth I cut out all the noise. I would only check follow one influencer that whose content seemed geniune, like yourself,  whenever I needed to learn technique. After that it was a breeze. Just had to keep showing up to the gym and sticking to the foundamentals.

 Keep it up the good work man üëçüèæ.
comments.author: @HeReignsBCAD

comments.text: I am so confused, always will be. I do push pull legs once a week like you say and I feel strong and great however, everyone says train muscles more frequently and I do worry I‚Äôm leaving gains on the table and it really stresses me out. I love the gym too and wish I could go more but I just can‚Äôt recover - maybe once every 5 days? Thanks
comments.author: @Williamsen10

comments.text: This is so true. The problem with following multiple influencers who are basically strangers, is that you constantly consider changing your routine!
comments.author: @HighIntensityMatt

comments.text: Do you think this is enough volume for the majority of natural lifters to make good gains? Your only doing like 8 sets per body part a week. Most of the research says you need 10-20 sets per week. I don't know the population they are geting the data from. Any of your thoughts on this would be greatly appreciated.
comments.author: @robarsenault8415

comments.text:
Can you please give your thoughts or help me about my 90 minutes fbeod where i do 2 sets for every safe compond  ( 1 heavy set 4-8 and 1 backoff set 8-12 )of

2- chest tbar and pull-upps 
3-machine shoulders press 
4- hack squat and hamstring 
5- lateral raises (dumbel +  cable)
6-biceps curl on incline
7- 1set jm press smith and 1 set unilateral triceps extension 
8- superset for forearms

comments.text: How do you have such big arms if the UL split is what built a majority of your physique? Often you only have 1 exercise each for bicep and tricep. Is that enough?
comments.author: @theoverseer3552

comments.text:

comments.text:
I haven't lifted seriously in more than 30 years. I just restarted. I got fantastic results in my teens by following a program very similar to this one. I developed the program myself - also inspired by Arthur Jones and Mike Mentzer. In 18 months I went from a weak and skinny 135 pounds at 15 years of age to 175 pounds at 5'10" at 17 years of age. With only 6.75" wrists and 8.5" ankles my upper arms taped 16" (with pump) and I was able to bench press 275 for 5 good reps and deadlift 405 for 5 reps. I was lean with prominent abs and 32" waist. The key is definitely steady progression and exercise selection along with high intensity and plenty of rest. I grew so fast that I still have prominent stretch marks on the outside of my chest and tops of my quads - and this was not only no drugs, but no supplements. Unfortunately, I suffered a serious injury that caused me to stop (tip: never do upright rows).

In my opinion, most people are either unwilling or unable to generate the necessary high intensity. I am outlier in this regard. I can really bring it! Unfortunately, I failed to curb my enthusiasm and likely overtrained later on leading to injury. High intensity absolutely requires a reduced volume and frequency. But again, most people do not appreciate this fact because they simply CANNOT or WILL NOT generate the necessary intensity! You can work out hard, OR you can work out for a long time and/or often- YOU CAN'T DO BOTH!
comments.author: @MarcosBuenijo1973

comments.text: Intensity over volume üî• 6-10 sets/week has been golden for me. 2 sets a piece using double progression. Each set is close to failure but you don't get the crazy rep drop off as you do with higher set counts.
comments.author: @barbellbryce

comments.text: Inspiring, I'm currently doing a upper, rest, lower, rest, repeat. Not sure if this is working for me yet, maybe too soon to tell? But I've noticed that i am a bit stronger when hitting on the fifth day instead of every 4:th day. (Specially on upper days). Lower days i do more hypertrophy kind of workout. I would like to try this method since I've studied M. M's a little bit. But I'm slightly confused of how many reps i should do? Since one set can vary between low weight with high rep range, or heavy weight with lower rep range. Or do you stick to between 8~12 reps/set, any advice? Thanks for sharing and don't stop inspiring.
comments.author: @Sahasrara369

comments.text: Your 3x per week workout plan is almost identical to what I'm already doing. The only difference is I'm not doing 2x exercises for rear delts - only 1x, but I add shrugs. Your traps are very well developed, so maybe I don't need shrugs, what do you think, Eric? I was contemplating a 4x per week push+legs, pull+legs, so everything is worked 2x per week, but I'm a bit weary about switching programs as it isn't always warranted. I'm happy to see you have success with this channel - I watched almost from the start. You're a genuine guy and deserve it. Thanks, Eric! Mi≈Çego dnia!
comments.author: @JaRozumiem

comments.text: Coming back to this video because after 10 years, I'm considering these methods. The caveat is..... I train at home with barbells/dumbbells. Do you legitimately suggest that I should take lifts like RDLs and squats right up to failure with 1 set? Or, would doing a bit more volume make more sense at my advancement level and equipment situation. I don't wanna get injured man!

comments.text:
I trained 3x per week now using push pull legs split
My push day is like incline bench, shoulder press, cable lateral raise, overhead tricep ext., triceps pushdown

Legs : squat, leg extension, leg curls, dumbell rdl
I train each set to failure ( until i cant lift it except for bench press/squat, i got 1 rep in reserve)
Do u think this is a good routine? 
Well im progressing like having 2 extra rep per exercise per week
But i really appreciate ur opinion on this :D
Good content as always mann

comments.text: 44 years old and full body twice a week. Hard training, compound movements, ample recovery, light cardio and time for other things outside the gym. Made excellent progress!
comments.author: @colin4215

comments.text:
I summarised the key points for anyone who wants something to have for reference later:

Lifting is the #1 priority -You need to be lifting with adequate intensity.

Eat around maintenance-No dirty bulk or starvation cut. Slightly above if you're trying to put on size or slightly below if you want to lean out.

Protein is paramount-  Roughly 1g per goal body weight.

Get enough sleep.

Ultimately, recomp comes from your body pulling fat stores for energy. Make slow steady progress, shortcuts do not work.
comments.author: @tk006

comments.text:
Certain HIIT workout can build muscle and burn fat at the same time and you can drop weight at the same time.  I personally am getting great muscle gains from doing Busy dad Burpee program. I have heard very similar results from people programing kettlebell training. You can wear a fitness band that tracks  heart rate and pick a weight and rep count or interval that can Savely get you into high zone 3 or even zone 4.

Even worse, Tom Platz said to do breathing squats for weight loss and leg gains.  Squat heavy as weight 50 times in 5reps, 20 sets, without putting the weight down. Catch your breath in between sets.

Build muscle, lose fat, and weight goes down.
